I watched it again yesterday afternoon and found it to be even better than I thought despite a few minor quibbles.Firstly, I agree that a few teabags of heroin didn't warrant all this fuss, but the idea of a cute/ creepy kid's doll stuffed with it is a malevolent image all the same. What puzzles me more is why on earth Susy risks her life for it when she has absolutely no idea what's in it. She even at one point says "I'm saving my husband's life aren't I?" which is completely out of nowhere. She suspects for as while it is evidence of her husband's implication in a murder or perhaps adultery plot, but she doesn't have any idea what is going on and yet risks her life for it. If it was me, even if I did know what was in the doll, I'd still hand it over to Roat!The other slight flaw in the film comes in its origins as a stage play. While the claustrophobia is a great asset, the problem lies in the adaptation not taking into account the reactions of a cinema audience are different to a theatre audience. Take for example the scene early on when Susy enters the flat while the three villains are meeting there. Why doesn't Roat tell them she is blind, he has time to? Because on stage one of the plays most effective moments was having Susy enter and face the villains and then the penny drops for the audience that she cannot see. This "shared reaction" of an audience is something pretty unique to theatre and needs heightening considerably to work on film.Additionally, the sequence where Susy realises the operator is still hanging on the phone line is a crowd pleasing laugh on stage but is not an effective gag in a movie.Minor quibbles though in a marvelous film. Very creepy music, wonderful acting, tension building very effectively (a particularly powerful moment being Susy's gasp as she realises Mike is one of the gang)and isn't Samantha Jones gorgeous?

reviews.review_title: A Knockout Climax Tops a Genuinely Taut Thriller That Still Holds Up Well
reviews.content: Watching Alan Arkin play the curmudgeonly grandfather in this year's "Little Miss Sunshine", one tends to forget what an exciting and versatile actor he was back in the mid-1960's. Here he has a field day playing Harry Roat, a coolly intelligent psycho intent on taking a doll filled with heroin from a blind woman, whose husband inadvertently left it in their apartment. This sharply effective 1967 thriller was the last movie Audrey Hepburn made before her nearly decade-long, self-imposed retirement. She ended fifteen years of transcendent performances with her superb portrayal of Susy Hendrix, a photographer's recently blinded wife just getting used to living with her new limitations. Her gradual evolution from seemingly helpless to surprisingly resourceful is what grounds the terror-ridden film in humanity.The plot begins at the airport where a mysterious young woman asks Susy's unsuspecting husband Sam to keep the doll for her. He takes it back to their Greenwich Village basement apartment where the rest of the vice-gripping plot takes place. Sam leaves Susy alone, and three men insinuate themselves into the place, one posing as Sam's old college friend to gain her trust. Roat plays three different people in his sadistic attempt to get Susy to hand over the doll. You can take it from there, but it does lead to a corking, no-holds-barred finale between Roat and Susy brilliantly executed. Without mentioning any particulars, the heart-stopping lunge (described colorfully in the DVD featurette) is a memorable piece of fright cinema.Credit needs to go to director Terence Young who sets the wheels of the rope-tightening plot with precision, and the economic screenplay by Robert and Jane Howard-Carrington based on the Frederick Knott play. Granted there are some contrived elements but you can figure them out yourself. There are solid contributions from Richard Crenna and Jack Weston as Roat's cohorts, Julie Herrod as the petulant teen-aged neighbor and Efrem Zimbalist, Jr. as Sam. Henry Mancini composed the cocktail lounge-style 1960's title song, but he also wrote the tense, strings-squealing music score. The 2003 DVD contains one worthwhile extra, an eight-minute, looking-back featurette containing interviews with Arkin and producer Mel Ferrer (just ending his marriage to Hepburn at the time of filming). There are also two theatrical trailers, the original and a cheesier one where the audience is told the lights will be completely darkened for the film's last eight minutes.

A fine thriller this movie is. "Wait Until Dark" is a movie that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The plot, the characters, the dialog, what more could you ask for? You got a woman named Susy Hendrix(Audrey Hepburn) who lost her sight in an accident living independently in her apartment, who unknowingly has a doll that is loaded with dope.Her neighbor, a young girl happens to be on her side at all times. There you got these seedy characters who's leader with the dark glasses carries this nude statuette named "Geraldine", who happens to be a switchblade in disguise. With fear and confusion that cripples Susy, she has no choice but to take action for herself. The guy who was close to Susy meets his end with "Geraldine" which I think is a stinker, and the killer get what he deserve, and the doll, let's not talk about that. This movie is too exciting to say out loud, you'll have to see it to believe it. I did! 5 Stars!

reviews.review_title: Decent but overrated "thriller" with a great Hepburn and some really forced, even corny aspects. Watch Arkin leap out at the end. Haha!
reviews.content: Wait until Dark (1967)I wish this was a better movie. I love Audrey Hepburn, and she's truly the star here trying to make the limited script work. I don't know that she plays a blind person quite right, but good enough for me. She's charming.The other highlight is the up and down performance of Alan Arkin in an early role. When he's the sunglass wearing psycho looking for the heroin in the doll he's pretty good, but when he puts on disguises and plays other roles he's kind of silly, though maybe that's intentional. Of the remaining four characters, no one is quite right on (the girl, I suppose) and the cop/thief played by Jack Weston is too exaggerated for my taste.This is a play, to be sure, made for film. That changes some of our expectations, in theory, but in a way that makes the script, which is the weakest point, even weaker. Plays, above all, have to be finely tuned in their dialog, their concepts, their economy. This one is such a huge strain, especially in the middle parts, it's hard to not laugh at it a bit. I'm not saying it's not horrifying in concept—a blind woman being tormented by some thugs to get information out of her she actually might not have—but the delivery is canned and so compacted in this screen version, shot almost entirely in an apartment, is just creaks.You do get the feeling this is supposed to the be the equal of say "Rope" or "Rear Window" by Hitchcock, which just shows you the limits of many directors and scripts because this doesn't have the depth, the visual panache, the psychological twists, of a good Hitch. It does have some of the 1960s falseness that pervaded the industry (including Hitchcock's films), and I have never quite acquired a taste for it. 1967 marks the birth of "New Hollywood" and a vigorous, fresh kind of filmmaking that is rather the opposite of this. For good reason.I've seen this three or four times over the years, and every time I say, maybe I'll like it this time. Nope, not quite. It's fun, it's good, and it's got very good moments —and it's got Audrey—but that's not quite, not at all quite enough. It does have a great finale, however, and it has some really bizarrely inventive music by Mancini using quartertones on the piano. So, there are aspects...give them some effort.
The film is really very surprising and breathtaking! You can feel the tension in your veins while watching it.

100 mins of pure suspense: A trio tries to take back the heroin stuffed doll from a blind woman's house. Halfway through the movie, we will feel like we are in the house and in the last 20 mins, we will be like "someone please help her." All credits to Audrey Hepburn performance and the direction.If you like Hitchcock's films, you can give this a try which is not his film. Don't Breathe (Post #18) maybe a contemporary version of Wait Until Dark, a classic thriller.How to watch: Turn of all the lights, watch in complete darkness to get better experience.

reviews.review_title: A thriller in every sense of the word
reviews.content: I think what really makes WAIT UNTIL DARK such a disturbing andgripping thriller is how the fact that the premise is so realistic. It can basically happen to anybody!! Audrey Hepburn is perfect as Susie, a blind woman caught up in a conspiracy when her husband Sam (Efram Zimbalist Jr) is given a toy doll with a very special secret inside. A trio of professional crooks (Richard Crenna, Jack Weston, and asuper-creepy Alan Arkin) want that doll, and discover that their hopes of retrieving it lies within Susie's handicap. Filled with joltingsuspense (check out the chilling, if not totally believable climax) and great performances between Hepburn and Arkin, WAIT UNTIL DARK wins as a one-of-a-kind thriller movie.

reviews.review_title: I had problems with aspects of the scenario but it was delivered really well
reviews.content: Sam Hendrix is a drug smuggler using a young woman to carry his stuff. When a doll stuffed with heroin goes missing her bosses suspect she is stealing and kill her. They still can't find the doll so the dangerous Harry Roat enrols the help of crooked cops Talmin and Carlino. Problem is that the doll is most likely somewhere in the apartment that Lisa shared with the newly blinded woman Susy. As night falls the three men set up a way into her flat using a variety of false ids.If you can get passed the illogical parts of this story then the end result is actually quite an enjoyable and tense little stage play. The doll could be anything and could contain anything because it is only a device that sets up the scenario. From here the film plays a nice game while Susy gradually puts the pieces together  it may not have mystery but it is still quite tense because, although we know what is going on, the fact is that we don't know what Susy is going to do. The apartment location is surprisingly well used because it could have easily been too stagy and static. Young moves the story around the room well but mainly it is the cast that make it work as well as it does.Hepburn may not always look convincing as a blind woman (she seems to lead with her eyes in a way that is unconvincing) but it is her fear and trust that she brings across well, making the character believable and engaging. Arkin is just as good but has less screen time; he is menacing while being charming and he makes a memorable villain that has a good part of the final scenes in the apartment. Crenna will be the guy from Rambo to the majority of people but he is effective here  delivering his lines with one tone while his face says something else. Weston and Zimbalist provide good support but the film belongs generally to the main three and specifically to Hepburn.Overall an enjoyable little thriller that builds well within the confines of the apartment block. The story may not be perfect but the cast work hard to more than make up for it; along with good use of the space, they deliver the story and characters in a convincing fashion.

reviews.review_title: The Dark Side of Audrey Hepburn
reviews.content: Audrey Hepburn first made her name in romantic comedies like "Roman Holiday" and "Sabrina", but throughout her career she tried to extend her range as an actress by alternating these with more serious films. Thus she followed up "Sabrina" with "War and Peace" and "Breakfast at Tiffany's" with "The Children's Hour". Today, however, it is her lighter films that tend to be remembered by the public; with the exception of "The Nun's Story" the serious ones are lesser known.Audrey never made a film with Alfred Hitchcock- she probably had the wrong colouring for a director who famously preferred blondes as his leading ladies- although according to her biographer Robyn Karney he did approach her to star in a film called "No Bail for the Judge", which in the event was never made. She did, however, star in two films in the sixties which both, in different ways, showed the influence of the great man. The first was Stanley Donen's "Charade", a light-hearted thriller-cum-romance in the style of "North by Northwest". The second, made four years later, was "Wait Until Dark", a much tenser, darker thriller which owes a greater debt to Hitchcock's dark side.This film perhaps shows us the dark side of Audrey Hepburn. She plays Susy Hendrix, a young woman who has lost her sight in an accident and who is slowly learning to cope with her blindness. The plot is a complex one and centres upon a classic Hitchcockian McGuffin, a doll stuffed with heroin. The doll has come into the possession of Susy and her husband Sam, who are quite unaware of its contents. A criminal named Harry Roat is desperate to recover the doll, and in order to do so he employs a couple of con-men who devise an elaborate ruse which involves one of them posing as an old wartime comrade of Sam and the other as a policeman. Susy is at first taken in, but gradually comes to suspect that the men are not what they seem, leading to a tense final confrontation between her and Roat. He might appear to have all the advantages, being both sighted and a violent, ruthless thug up against a defenceless blind girl. The title of the film does, however, point to one thing she has on her side. To compensate for her blindness she has developed acute hearing, so she is at an advantage in the dark and sets about smashing all the light-bulbs in her flat.Audrey was not only the most beautiful actress of her generation, but also one of the most charismatic. She had the ability to make almost any film she starred in her property to the extent that it becomes impossible to imagine any other actress taking the leading role. "Wait Until Dark", based on a stage play hardly anyone has ever heard of, could have been just another routine thriller; instead, it is an Audrey Hepburn vehicle, which means that it becomes something special. Susy, vulnerable and frightened yet courageous and determined, is one of her most lovable characters. She did a lot of preparatory work for the film, attending a school for the blind and even learning to read braille, and this obviously paid off. We always accept Susy as blind, even though we know perfectly well that Audrey herself was not.The success of the film is not due to Audrey alone. There is a good performance from Alan Arkin as the creepy psychopath Roat, and the direction is skilfully handled by Terence Young. The last twenty minutes, when Roat confronts Susy in the darkened flat, are particularly gripping- a scene of which Hitchcock would have been proud. I have read that the fact that the action is confined to a single flat betrays the film's origins as a stage play. In my view, however, Young was quite right to resist any temptation to "open it up"; this concentration on a single enclosed location is necessary to create an atmosphere of claustrophobia and tension. (The recent Jodie Foster thriller "Panic Room", which also features a woman in danger from three criminals and which owes a lot to "Wait Until Dark", was similarly confined to a single house, although that was based on an original screenplay, not a stage play).This was Audrey's last film before her nine-year absence from the cinema (due to events in her private life), but she was still clearly an actress at the height of her powers. "Wait Until Dark", like "The Nun's Story", "The Unforgiven" and "The Children's Hour", is evidence that she was not just the Queen of the romantic comedy but also a very versatile actress. 8/10

The problem with this film is its dubious story.  The villain, Roat, conceives a plan that requires that he change his disguise, and further requires that he manipulate two other people.  I can see how a psychopath might be intelligent and clever.  What defies belief is how someone preoccupied with drugs could be so inventive, so creative, so quick-witted, and so resourceful.  Had the object of his attention been something other than drugs, a valuable gem for example, the premise might have had more credibility.To further the plot along, Roat's complex scheme requires an intelligent victim. And thus, Susy Hendrix, although blind, is super alert, quick-witted, and resourceful.  Helping Susy is Gloria, the glasses-wearing, precocious teen.Indeed, "Wait Until Dark" gushes with smart characters who know exactly what to say and do, at exactly the right moment.  The result is a story that comes across as affected and artificial, a conclusion further supported by the film's implausible ending.If the story is weak, the acting is not.  Alan Arkin is terrific as the villain.  Both Crenna and Weston give credible performances.  And who could criticize the demure and likable Audrey Hepburn?  Not me.This movie does belong in the "thriller" genre.  But its suspense is diluted somewhat by a too talky script, the result perhaps of its origin as a play.Overall, "Wait Until Dark" is a good movie to watch once, mainly for the acting achievements of Arkin and Hepburn.

reviews.review_title: Alan Arkin and Audrey Hepburn make this worth seeing, although the film is really quite good in other respects also
reviews.content: Audrey Hepburn was nominated for an Oscar and how Alan Arkin missed out on one for Supporting Actor I'll never understand.  The performances carry the film, although there is a very good supporting cast, afairly decent script and production values are good. The performances by epburn and Arkin raise the film from average to excellent. Recommended

This is probably one of the most intense films of all time.  This film is so intense that I often have a hard time viewing it due to its intensity. Audrey Hepburn is perfect as Susy as she fights of a Roat, probably the biggest creep in the history of cinema.  I'm surprised that Alan Arkin wasn't at least nominated along with Hepburn for an Oscar.  This was certainly a different role for Arkin, who usually plays the typical neurotic New Yorker.  However, this is one instance in which the Academy shows its usual bias against unlikeable characters.  I'm also surprised that the film itself wasn't even nominated for an Oscar.  As someone said earlier, todays horror directors should look at this classic and take notes.  This film proves that a good horror film can be frightening without being overly gory.

never have i ever seen a movie so thrilling that i have actually dreaded finishing it because i was having so much fun. there isn't a single part in the entire movie where you feel like you can take a second to look down at the bucket of popcorn and grab a handful because you know that as soon as you do you will miss something important and you wouldn't want to do that. right from the beginning with the airport scene the audience is given a sort of creepy feeling about what is going on and we cheer for the woman because she is portrayed similarly to a julia roberts in pretty woman (a prostitute trying to get away from her demanding pimp). although its clear that this person has never been the woman's friend and they will certainly never will. the entire premise of hepburn's blindness is amazing. i heard that they had to give her special contact lenses because her eyes were too intense for a blind person. isn't that mind-blowing? everything took off smoothly and the whole flight was without turbulence. although the landing was a tad jolty it left the viewer satisfied non the less. even when it seems as though hepburn's character is about to get killed she manages to get out of the situation smoothly. despite our crestfallen feelings of her surely impending doom after seeing her struggling to pick up a few household cutlery, she manages to prove not only to us but also to her husband that she can be a champion blind.

reviews.review_title: An excellent thriller, made in the finest Hitchcock tradition
reviews.content: When I'm watching a thriller, I'm not very easy to please and yet I am. I just don't want to see too many big explosions, enormous car chases, big stunts,... All I want is a good story with some fine character development, a nice decor and a lot of tension. The only problem is that not too many thrillers - and certainly not the most recent ones - meet that prescription. The ideas of people like Alfred Hitchcock are very often copied, but almost never met, let alone exceeded. So from time to time I like to watch 'old' thrillers like for instance this one. (A movie that has been created 11 years before your birth always feels old, but that doesn't mean that it isn't good of course)."Wait Until Dark" starts with a meeting between Sam and a mysterious woman at an airport. She asks him to hold a doll for her and soon after disappears without a trace. She is found dead in Susie's apartment by two small time criminals called Mike and Carlino. Susie is Sam's wife and has recently been blinded because of an accident. That's why she doesn't know that there was a dead woman in her place, put there and already removed again by Harry Rote, or that the doll - for which the woman was murdered - was stuffed with heroin. But by know, Susie has heard on the radio that a dead woman was found in the neighborhood and when Sam has to leave home for his work for a couple of days, she doesn't feel too safe. In the mean time, Mike, Carlino and Harry Rote have teamed up to find the doll and invent a story of a police investigation. They tell Susie that Sam is the suspect in the murder case and that the doll will link him to the body. At first everything seems to go well as they try to convince Susie of giving them the doll, but Rote is a cold killer and starts to loose his patience...As this movie proves: a good thriller doesn't need many sets or characters to be very effective. The biggest part of the movie is situated in the confined space of Susie's apartment and almost all the time there are only four characters that you'll see. Nothing more, nothing less. And it works perfectly. Thanks to the fine story and the excellent acting by Audrey Hepburn, Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna and Jack Weston, this movie never seems to loosen its grip on you. You just stay interested from the beginning until the end as the tension and suspense more and more start to build up. What I also admire in this movie is the fact that it all feels so timeless. It feels a bit like a Hitchcock movie. He too knew how to make excellent thriller that, even though made almost forty years ago, still stands. Nothing seems to remind you of the fact that this is an 'old' movie. Sure, there are some smaller details - like a car or an airplane - that will show you that this isn't one of last year's movies, but overall this movie has aged perfectly. As a conclusion I would like to say that if you are interested in a very nice thriller with some nice acting, a great story full of suspense and a timeless feeling, than I wouldn't think twice and watch this little gem. I reward it with at least a 7.5/10, although I believe that an 8/10 isn't exaggerated either.

A blind woman is terrorized by hoodlums intent on retrieving heroin that they believe is hidden in her apartment. Hepburn is fine as the blind woman, while Arkin and Crenna are OK as the bad guys. Zimbalist plays Hepburn's husband as an annoying nincompoop. There are some suspenseful moments, but it is hard to get past the stupidity of the script, which is unbelievably contrived. It is hard to buy that Hepburn is so trusting of Crenna a few minutes after meeting him. The lengths that the bad guys go to with disguises to fool a blind woman is silly. Despite the flaws in the script, it could have been made into a fine film by someone more talented than Young.

reviews.review_title: Feels too manufactured like a play
reviews.content: Roat (Alan Arkin) is a drug dealer, but his girl Lisa passed his drugs to an unsuspecting fellow traveler. The heroin is stuffed in a doll and Roat can't find it. So he devise a complicated plan. He hires two fellow criminals Carlino (Jack Weston) and Mike Talman (Richard Crenna). They play act their way into the apartment while the man is away leaving only the blind wife Susy Hendrix (Audrey Hepburn).The whole setup is way too complicated. It seems to be a desperate way to get three crooks to lie to a blind woman only to have her outsmart them all. But I just can't let the setup go. It feels too fragile like the smallest disruption would put the story into collapse.Audrey Hepburn is wonderful as the blind woman. Alan Arkin is too mannered in his acting as the creepy crook. Is he trying to be a cartoon? Both Richard Crenna and Jack Weston provide solid characters. The acting in general is well above average.Maybe a play works better. It's a more artificial place to watch a story. Having a fake unreasonable story doesn't diminish it as much on stage. When it's adapted to the screen, it needs to be tight.

reviews.review_title: The best Hitchcock movie Hitchcock never made
reviews.content: This is a very enjoyable and suspenseful picture and quite frightening in moments. Well done cinematically, although it is often a bit too obvious that this is basically a stage play. However, many of the most suspenseful moments are more suspenseful because they are in the language of cinema rather than stage. Frequently the composition accentuates a sensation of claustrophobia which contributes a lot to the suspense.I refer to this picture as "The Best Hitchcock Movie Hitchcock Never Made" because it has many hallmarks of the master's work. First, a quick story summary: recently blinded woman unwittingly comes into possession of a doll which an evil criminal and two henchmen are after. The criminals create a rather involved plot to wrest the doll from the blind woman's possession and mayhem ensues.First, we have the doll. This is a classic "MacGuffin" in the Hitchcock tradition. A MacGuffin is an object on which the plot hangs, which drives the characters' actions. It could be anything -- a box of chocolates with diamonds inside, a slip of paper with incriminating evidence -- it doesn't matter what the item is that pushes the story along, and indeed we don't know what the doll contains until the last couple of reels -- precisely because it is inconsequential to the workings of the film.Second, we have the central suspense-building technique of the film, which is that the audience knows what is going on while the protagonist does not. The blindness of the central character affords wide latitude in exploiting this idea. It is a technique often used by Hitch to manipulate the audience, memorably for example in Sabotage and Rope, to name only two. It works here to great effect.Third, there is really only one "jump out and say boo!" moment in the movie and it is extraordinarily well-timed. After the suspense has been built to a fever pitch and artificially deflated there is an almost cathartic moment of leap-out-of-your-seat-and-scream shock before the last suspenseful moments. Compare it to Psycho, for example, and the final moments in the basement in that picture -- a similar effect on the audience.Fourth, yes, as some other comments have said, the criminals' plot is a little too involved to be realistic. But like the doll it exists only to produce suspense in the audience. On this level it richly succeeds. Hitchcock by and large dismissed credibility as key to a plot (read Hitchcock/Truffaut for many interesting thoughts on this). If the film is to engage the suspense of the audience on a cinematic level, to such an extent that they suspend their disbelief, the plot's purpose is to provide a framework in which this can occur. Again, the picture works on this level.Richard Crenna is as wooden as ever, though. His range and depth make me think of what Andie McDowell would have been like if she had been born a male tough-guy. Hepburn does a fine job with difficult material. Arkin convinces as the psychotic criminal.While not on a par with Hitchcock's best work one would have liked to have seen what the master would have done with this material.

One of my favorite films, Audrey Hepburn terrificly portrays a blind woman who unkowingly possesses a doll that has heroin hidden inside and three men who will do anything to get it back. A wonderful script and cast Alan Arkin, who plays a wonderful villian,proves that he can play well in a suspense movie and comedies. Anyways this movie is a must see

reviews.review_title: "Do I have to be the world's champion blind lady?"
reviews.content: A clever screenplay and a tight plot deliver a neat psychological thriller, with Audrey Hepburn portraying a blind woman who's the target of a vicious criminal intent on retrieving some heroin hidden in a doll her husband received in an unintended hand-off at the airport. Whew! It sounds complicated but it's really not once the story gets going. This one will keep you fascinated with it's subtle twists with the characters, resulting in a convincing climax as the handicapped woman wins out against her tormentors.One thing I thought the writers were going for though resulted in no follow through. At one point, crooked cop Talman (Richard Crenna) makes a slow, deliberate call to the phone booth outside Susy Hendrix's apartment, and the attentive viewer will figure she's counting the dial clicks to realize it's the same number he gives her for his police contact. That seemed a wasted moment for me, since Susy was so resourceful in every other respect. Another point, when Susy prepares for her showdown with Roat (Alan Arkin), she eliminates all the light sources in her apartment, but the ones she simply unscrews by hand would have burned her without protection, so that seemed like an unforced error in the story.So the picture is a half century old as I write this, and if you need to be convinced such a thing as inflation exists, how about Talman asking for two hundred fifty bucks up front for him and partner Carlino (Jack Weston) to fall in with Roat? What! - mere chickenfeed today for the enterprising criminal. And then, when neighbor Gloria shows up at the apartment with two full bags of groceries for five bucks, I knew we were still in the Twilight Zone era.For all that, the picture still delivers pretty well in the suspense department, and the coup de grace in the script occurred when Gloria made her two-ring telephone signal to Susy that second time, and she realized the outside phone booth connected Talman with Roat. Still, I had to wonder when it was all over if it was really worth it for Roat to kill three victims for those few bags of heroin he pulled out of the doll. I'm not up on my drug prices, but it didn't seem like there was that much there for him to get so intense about. Even so, Arkin was convincing in his role, all three of them if you count the impersonations, but then again, why go through all that for a blind lady?

Fairly good, fairly tense suspenser, with many clever touches. Terrifically acted by Hepburn (much more likable here than she was in "My Fair Lady", where she was likable in a forced way)and Crenna (whose performance is neglected). The film is marred only by Arkin's performance, which was too showy.

reviews.review_title: IF THIS WAS REAL LIFE, WHAT WOULD HAVE REALLY HAPPENED?
reviews.content: Can't argue with that line! You could only wonder too what Hitchcock would have done with Audrey Hepburn's character, emmm? Whatever the case, this thriller is mesmerizing, especially if you are catching this for the very first time. Fantastic stuff! And even if you've seen this, WAIT UNTIL DARK is well worth another look or two for some dynamic acting, on the part of Hepburn, and one ingenious script that delivers in spades! This IS the classic intersection where good story telling and imagination (on steroids) come together, make no mistake. It could also be compared to a revamped, 60s-style PERILS OF PAULINE opus, where poor Audrey has to somehow, someway rise above it all, and being blind is just pushing the envelope a little further, if you will! Who's keeping score? This is high camp stuff that will keep you on the edge of your seat, and if there's a bit of Hitchcockian flavor in this, perhaps, it has to be the fates awaiting the bad guys here. KARMA CENTRAL. Just what the doctor ordered for all of us arm chair thriller seekers at heart! PS: Don't forget to check your light bulbs!

There's nothing particularly challenging about this story of Audrey Hepburn being constantly threatened by three villains. Would anyone call "Dial M For Murder" in any way pregnant with a message? Nope. It's designed to entertain, from beginning to end, and it gets the job done.Hepburn's husband has inadvertently given her a doll containing a large amount of heroin and then is off somewhere on a trip, out of the picture, unable to help, as husbands and boyfriends in these movies always are. This leaves the innocent and blind Hepburn alone in her basement apartment in New York, her only possible assistant a snotty young girl who lives upstairs.Audrey Hepburn was fortyish and no longer a naive young lass but retained her classic features and reed-thin modelesque figure. She does as professional a job here as she did anywhere else.The three villains who are in cahoots in an attempt to find out what Hepburn did with the heroin doll are diverse. Richard Crenna is the only one who is young and handsome and he's not unsympathetic. Allan Arkin knocks him off. Jack Weston is the dumb and brutal soldier of the group. Allan Arkin knocks him off.Arkin himself is the brains. He's given to wearing shades and black leather. He carries a switchblade and his hair is cut in bangs across his forehead. The single most startling moment in the film is given to him. I won't describe it except to call it "The Leap." It worked so well that it's been imitated a dozen times since. The only problem I had with Arkin as a ruthless murderer is that he's such a nice guy. He really is. And to see him lurching around in the darkness trying to cut the throat of someone as appealing as Audrey Hepburn is -- well, "casting against type" can be carried too far.Frederick Knott has structured the play in an almost classical way, beginning with happiness, satisfaction, and normality -- for those who find happiness and satisfaction in normality -- and then introducing the threat, and building on it, bit by bit, until the fulminating climax.You won't be bored for a minute.

Audrey Hepburn says something not true in the movie. She says she's not a good blind woman.  Well, she seemed to me to make a completely convincing blind woman.  The movie is still good for a thrill or two and I liked Alan Arkin, who seemed to enjoy playing the heavy.  I would have liked to have seen what Robert Duvall did with the part on Broadway, but Arkin is very well cast.  This is not the case with Richard Crenna, who did not convince for one minute.  The movie is a classic of the 'blind woman in distress' genre.

Yes, far far better for me than 23 PACES TO BAKER STREET, from director Hank Hathaway, back in the fifties, where Van Johnson was in the nearly same role, same scheme as Audrey Hepburn here. But this is not a remake, the Hathaway's film was a murder, assassin intrigue, nothing to do with drug traffic. Here, Mel Ferrer's wife in real life is of course excellent, but I will mainly remind terrific because so ambivalent Richard Crenna's character, and also Alan Arkin's one. A slow and boring beginning, to explain the elements, and then, whao !!! Terrific film for me, where the bad guys are shown in a very unusual way, and the fight between them and blind Audrey Hepburn is jawdropping.... Tense, taut, ths feature won't let you drop till the end. A movie critic, in 1968, seemed obsessed by the fact that the apartment door remained unlocked by Suzy - Hepburn - and that amused me. He may be right, this critic, but so many goofs appear all the time, if you watch closely enough. This is an excellent movie for me anyway. I know that there are some goofs here; for instance when villain Jack Weston enters Hepburn's apartment, when she is supposed to be alone before he gets in, WHY doesn't he get surprised to see the apartment with all his lights on? Lights on for a blind woman? Ha ha ha. And when, in the end, Suzy smashes all the lights, to be equal to her enemies, WHY does she let only one light on? Only to let the audience continue to watch? Ha ha ha. And the matches trick in the end, with the gasoline threat, for the villain Arkin, is a very smart way to permit the audiences to watch thru total darkness....

Wait Until Dark (1967): Dir: Terence Young / Cast: Audrey Hepburn, Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna, Jack Weston, Julie Herrod: Spellbinding psychological thriller about time and condition as a blind woman, played by Audrey Hepburn discovers ominous strangers presenting themselves in her apartment seeking a doll. It conceals drugs and Alan Arkin seeks assistance from fellow criminals Richard Crenna and Jack Weston in order to gain trust into the whereabouts. Director Terence Young makes great use of lighting as the apartment becomes eerie and ominous. Young previous directed a few James Bond outings before graduating to this. Hepburn is well cast as the blind heroine who slowly learns to use her limitations to her advantage during key moments. Arkin is brilliant as this sadistic killer whose methods are sly, cunning and deadly until his overconfidence becomes his enemy. Crenna and Weston are superb as blackmailed con men out to talk Hepburn out of the doll she knows nothing about. Crenna in particular begins to develop romantic feelings towards her. Julie Herrod plays a young girl in the building who allies herself with Hepburn as sort of watch out. Shocking masterpiece right down to its nail biting conclusion where limitations are advantages when pride overshadows the realization that the darkness waited upon may be the blessing of survival. Score: 10 / 10

reviews.review_title: Kill the lights and prepare for terror!
reviews.content: Wait Until Dark is a classy, suspenseful horror movie that should be watched in total darkness for the fullest effect. Audrey Hepburn gives a show-stopping performance as the blind Susie Hendrix. She combines vulnerability and resourcefulness perfectly, with her usual addition of charm and sympathy. You want to shout a warning to her, tell her that there's a dead woman in the closet and those around her aren't what they seem. She's matched, on the other end of the character spectrum, by Alan Arkin as cool, emotionless, sadistic Harry Roat. His smooth villainy and her immense appeal and impaired state ratchet the suspense sky-high. It's almost unbearable during the climax, in which we're literally left in the dark with only the sounds of Susie's screaming and Roat's labored grunting. I refuse to divulge any more, but it's quintessential nightmare material, and you'll never forget it. A superb, character-driven example of how elegance and intelligence can and should be used in horror films.

Wow! What a really great movie!*possible spoilers*1967's Wait Until Dark is a dark and ultimately intense thriller about a blind woman (Audrey Hepburn) whose home is invaded by criminals bent on recovering their lost doll. Yep, I said doll. But it turns out that this special doll is holding some drugs and crazy Alan Arkin will stop at nothing to get it.The cast of this film is excellent. Hepburn is as great as ever and Arkin is one great villain! The supporting cast is also good. Henry Mancini's music score is nicely creepy, a good help to the movie's unsettling mood. The setting is very claustrophobic. The story itself is a compelling suspense piece that builds to an unforgettable climax. This is one thriller that is not to be missed by genre fans!!**** out of ****

Adaptations of stage plays can cause considerable difficulties for filmmakers.WAIT UNTIL DARK is especially claustrophobic and stagey;but in this case,it actually works in it's favour.Terence Young directed some absolute howlers in his film career(ACTION OF THE TIGER,INCHON,BLOODLINE among them),but he made some very fine efforts too(DR NO,FROM Russia WITH LOVE,the two best James Bond films),including this one.The film starts off slowly and uncinematically,with a wordy,stage-bound setting up of the plot,but gradually suspense and thrills build up unto the rousing final duel between the blind Audrey Hepburn and psychotic murderer Alan Arkin.Both give first class performances;an excellent actor usually known for his comic roles,it's unusual to see Arkin playing such a maniac though he does it convincingly,and Hepburn makes you believe she is genuinely blind even in real life.The film's pulsating last 15 minutes are as gripping and thrilling a sequence as ever committed to celluloid,with superbly well-judged moments of nerve-jangling shock.The supporting performances are OK,but why didn't child actress Julie Herrod ever make another film? The final scenes between her,Audrey,and the usually rather stiff Efrem Zimbalist Jnr are very well done and touch the emotions.Henry Mancini's score is sometimes effective but seems on occasions overtly familiar to CHARADE(1963),an Audrey Hepburn/Cary Grant classic Mancini composed several years earlier.The film would've been absolutely outstanding if it wasn't for the indifferent opening scenes,and rather more light relief:the only bits of real humour come at the end credits,when we see Arkin credited as ROAT,ROAT JNR,and ROAT SNR(JNR and SNR were obviously impersonations as part of the subterfuge to steal the heroin-stuffed doll),but it's still a very good thriller nonetheless.

reviews.review_title: Thrillers don't come any better than this.
reviews.content: I ended up watching this film with absolutely no preconceptions whatsoever, due entirely to the fact that I had never heard of the film before, (ignorance rules o.k!).What I was presented with was an absolute feast of superb acting, Arkin & Hepburn especially. A plot that constantly led the viewer into a false sense of expectation, YES we knew Audrey was going to come out unscathed, but everything else in between ??? The girl who played 'Gloria' was sinister in her own right, & could surely have gone on & played many a possessed child in many a 'poltergeist' type film, had the opportunity arisen.Personally speaking, I have a very short attention span when it comes to movies of any kind, but this one gripped me from start to end. Arkin wouldn't have looked out of place in a 1990's pulp fiction genre. Scary, believable, superb! Hepburn was her usual vivacious self, apparently revelling in the blind woman against all odds scenario, superb!Two scary, sh** I wasn't expecting that, type of moments came in the form of the Arkin's car driving, & his incredible gymnastic spring towards the end. Corny maybe?, but so well done it can be totally forgiven.The fact is, that this could so very easily have become a very mediocre 'stage play to film' adaptation. What makes it that little bit special is very hard to pinpoint. Perhaps it's because it's NOT a Hitchcock, but could so very easily have been. One can only ponder how the master of suspense himself could have improved this gem of film?I would recommend anyone who watches this movie, to dim the lights to a mere glow, & prepare to be sucked in!& remember to guard your luggage just that little more carefully next time at the airport!

One thing that's noteworthy about Audrey Hepburn is that she retired from acting at a pretty young age. In fact, this was pretty much the last film she made for about 10 years. What that means is that she has a relatively limited (compared to other major stars) body of work - and what that means is that it's easy to get a pretty good look at her talents because you can easily watch a good chunk of what she did. I like Audrey Hepburn. She's very talented, and I've seen her in some superb roles. - but, although I'm sure she had personal reasons for her early retirement from the biz, I can also see why this movie might have pushed her in that direction. This was not one of her better movies, and although she herself was pretty good in it, this was also not one of her better performances.In "Wait Until Dark" Hepburn played Suzy Hendrix - a young woman who's gone tragically blind due to a car accident. Her husband has been duped into unknowingly bringing home a doll stuffed with heroin, and while he's away those who want the heroin start to work their way into her apartment and her life, trying to confuse her and then pressure her into giving them the doll. But somehow this tried way too hard to be a cloak and dagger, suspense thriller kind of movie. It packed too much into itself; there were - to use an analogy - too many moving parts. The end result was that rather than being thrilling or exciting or suspenseful, I actually found this rather dull and hard to follow. Hepburn put a lot into playing the part of the young blind woman (at times I wondered - would a blind person really do that? - but I'm willing to cut some slack just because of how difficult it must be for a sighted person to play a blind person) but the rest of the cast seemed at times to struggle, and I was especially unimpressed with Alan Arkin as Roat (the leader of the group trying to get the heroin filled doll) in one of his very early performances. I will grant that the climax of the movie, as Suzy and Roat confront each other in the apartment, is pretty exciting, which helped make me feel that there was a good reason for watching this. I confess that by about the halfway point I was starting to question why I bothered. Aside from Hepburn and Arkin it's a pretty limited cast including well known actors like Richard Crenna and Efrem Zimbalist, Jr. and a completely unknown young actress named Julie Herrod as young Gloria (who seems to be Suzy's sometimes friend and sometimes nemesis) who was actually not bad, but whose career never went anywhere. The limited cast and set (it basically all takes place inside Suzy's apartment) is probably a result of this having been adapted from a stage play.There was one thing in this that made me chuckle. Unless you're a Canadian you probably wouldn't pick up on this - but I wondered how much money somebody paid to advertise in various scenes of this movie. This was made in 1967 - Canada's Centennial year, and the year of Expo '67 in Montreal, which was the big - really BIG - Centennial event of that year in Canada. The beginning of the movie is filled with shots of Air Canada jets - one of which has "expo67" painted on its side, and there are various references to Canada and - especially - Montreal made in the film. It seemed like a pretty obvious "Come and visit!" type of ad - although the movie was released just as Expo was closing, I could see this being used as a way to entice people to keep coming back. (5/10)

I can't think of a better word to sum up this movie other than that: sinister. A movie has seldom unsettled me as much as Wait Until Dark. The plot, marvellous and inventive, must have come from the mind of either a genius or a sadist.Three criminals in pursuit of a doll full of heroin devise a plan to get into the apartment of a blind woman, Susy, try to con her into giving them the doll and, when that fails, decide to got for murder.This movie is full of chilling scenes; the first time Susy enters the apartment, the criminals are all there. They clutch to the walls, holding their breath, a corpse hanging from a bedroom closet. Then there's the whole plot of terrifying her into giving them the doll. And of course, there's the final confrontation, one of the best I've ever seen and which made me jump from my seat, something I almost never do. Throughout the movie there's just a sense of dread and evil, like something really horrible is about to happen, that will hold everyone's attention in thrall.Audrey Hepburn is incredible as Susy; she seems lost and vulnerable, but also has an upbeat look in her face. She also has a great trait I like in characters in thrillers: she's smart. Several times she outsmarts the villains, making her active instead of just a passive victim.Alan Larkin, however, steals the show as Harry Roat, a leather-jacket-wearing, sun-glass-inside-the-house-wearing, knife-loving villain. As smart as Susy and infinitely vicious, he's one of the great villains of the cinema.Wait Until Dark is a great thriller, very much in Hitchcock's style: there's a situation and an innocent person must get out of it. We know who the good and the bad are and what's at stake. It's the cat-and-game mouse, the outsmarting each other, that's fun to watch. And in this movie it's a perfect game of wits, where you're not certain until the end who'll win. What's certain is that no one will forget this movie.

reviews.review_title: This is a brilliant movie that is definitely a must see
reviews.content: Wait Until Dark (1967) is a movie I recently rewatched on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a blind woman in the big city whose husband returns home from a business trip when someone bumps into him at the airport and hands him a doll. When he returns home to his wife he discovers a murder just happened outside the house that shook his wife. He had a few errands to run and the entire time he's gone a series of visitors visit the blind wife to talk about the murder and looking for the mysterious doll. This movie is directed by Terence Young (From Russia with Love) and stars Audrey Hepburn (Breakfast at Tiffany's), Alan Arkin (Argo), Richard Crenna (First Blood) and Samantha Jones (Get to Know your Rabbit). This movie is outstanding and brilliantly intricate. The opening investigation sequence where the plot is revealed is intense and sets the movie up perfectly. Hepburn is amazing, like everything she's in, and the conclusion is unpredictable and surprisingly violent. There's a little girl in this that is appropriately, painfully annoying. The doll handoffs are a bit complex but are well throughout and executed leading to a magnificent conclusion. This is a brilliant movie that is definitely a must see and a 10/10.

Wait Until Dark is a good- not great- but very good suspense thriller about a blind woman left alone in her apartment being tormented by three characters who think there's a stash of heroin located somewhere inside. The principal actors in the film, Audrey Hepburn and Alan Arkin, are excellent and the plot is actually damn clever even though I found some slight holes in it. If you know anything about blind people, you know their other senses are much more alive, so it puzzles me that Audrey wouldn't know there were three- count 'em- three men in her apartment, including a dead body in a garment bag, no less, that she passes within a whisker of. And, in fact, later in the film, Audrey is able to hear Jack Weston's character dusting and indentify Alan Arkin's character as wearing the same pair of shoes as he poses in different identities. Also, why in the world would a bunch of shady drug dealers go to such lengths to weave this whole tapestry of a story to get Hepburn to turn over the missing doll?  Especially since it turns out there's not a hell of a lot of dope inside it, just a few packets worth. Arkin explains at the end "I tried to do it their way...but they're a couple of amateurs", but he's involved in the play-acting right up to his neck, appearing in fake wigs, moustaches, and accents.  And that's another thing: I like Alan Arkin a lot, and I always enjoy him in just about everything he's in, but whenever I see him playing around in different looks and voices, it just reminds me he'll never be anything more than a Peter Sellers wannabe.  All the same, this movie will legitimately keep you in suspense most of the way. And Henry Mancini's tick-tock musical score is superb.  *** out of 4

Well written thriller, with Audrey Hepburn almost as good as Lee Remick, in the New York play.  Really well directed, with a good atmospheric score by Henry Mancini, and a flawless supporting cast.  Will lose much of its theatrical scares (when I saw it in the theater, even the exit lights were turned out, during the match lighting scene) but still effective on television. One of Audrey Hepburn's best films.

reviews.review_title: You will remember this when you are alone.
reviews.content: After I watched this movie in the comforts of my own home, I really wished I could have lived at a time when I could have gone to a cinema on halloween night, 1967, and witnessed how the theater really was darkened to the legal limit so that the last 8 min. would be as scary as possible.This really is a milestone picture in the horror genre, just like Psycho before it and Halloween after it. It has many imitators that try to re-create a horror story, but fail. Even if the initial scare doesn't make you jump, (which, by the way, it probably will,) You will remember this when you are alone. After you wake up from a nightmare where an unseen evil is stalking you, you will think to yourself how would you protect yourself if you no seeing ability, or even if you could somehow make a defense. This is not a story of the supernatural, like in Halloween, a monster movie, like Alien, or a Bad-guy-that-won't-die movie, like in Friday the 13th. This is a story, where we are given the plot as if we are reading it from a book, where all the characters have emotions and motives for their actions, and where sometimes we find ourselves just as confused and blinded as Audrey Hepburn is, and that is what makes the terror real.

reviews.review_title: A physchological thriller of big proportions
reviews.content: Behind every corner, in every room, there is something lurking. Something evil is waiting. And just when you think you know what's going on, that you've figured it out, BOOM!!!! Out of nowhere comes an unexpected twist, an adventurous, bloodcurdling turn. Just wait until dark.   This movie, one in which Audrey Hepburn was nominated for her fifth (and final) Oscar nomination. Let me just say that she really, REALLY deserved it. Alan Arkin, who plays the creepy/eerie narcotics dealer (Roat) is just as horiffying in this suspense thriller as Audrey is beautiful. He schemes his way into Susie's apartment, searching for a doll full of heroin. Even though he's way ahead of Susie, basically because she's blind (but don't let that fact fool you, she's extremely brilliant) Susie figures out piece by piece what's going on. Roat's two henchmen, Mike and Carlino, are so-so in the acting department, but try their best to get the doll out of Susie.    Watch this during the night time, with the lights off, and it will change you. For one, don't mess with blind people, and two, don't think that just because a movie is made in the 60s that it won't be scary. This is scary, and suspenseful. Just watch....At night.....In the dark.

reviews.review_title: An enigmatic, ominous thriller with suspense to spare and the expert ability to put you in the shoes of its protagonist.
reviews.content: This enigmatic thriller's greatest strength lies in its ominous, suspenseful tone - helped immensely by its excellent, slightly off-key soundtrack and instantly gripping opening - which Young wisely knows when to push to the foreground or pull to the back while never letting it truly relent. It's interesting how the audience is able to not only know the intentions of the criminals but also understand the blind protagonist's perspective too. This means that the various reveals in 'Wait Until Dark (1967)' aren't shocking to us but they are to her, which is a move that shouldn't have worked yet strangely does incredibly well. It's in the way in which we see her come to understand the situation that we realise how terrifying it truly must be. The horror comes from how phenomenally we are put in the shoes of the protagonist, how vulnerable we feel when we relate to her. Then, it transforms slightly when she starts to embrace her relatively newfound world of literal darkness and fight back against those who would take advantage of her. It's when we start to see how determined and resourceful she truly is that the chills turn to thrills and pure excitement, but a hint of dread always remains. This leads into the feature's fantastically tense finale that uses its unique slant extremely well and finishes the piece on a high note. It's because our lead has to find her own way out of the never-safe situation that it all ends up so satisfying. 8/10

Alan Arkin has said that his role as Roats in this film was difficult for him, because he, like everybody else, did not enjoy having to terrorize a character played by lovely Audrey Hepburn. In fact, this was one of the reasons that the character of Roat was so hard to cast-but lets be glad Arkin finally took the role. He contributes quite a lot to this film. The film is based on a stage play of the same name, thus a lot of the action happens on one set. I generally find such films fairly boring, and the first time I saw this one I didn't find it all that interesting. But I so enjoyed the Roats character, that I went back and viewed it again-and this time I loved it. The film contains a few plot holes which some reviewers have pointed out, accurately, end up serving the film rather than detracting from it. Anyone who enjoys a good suspense film or movies with twists and surprises will love this one!

reviews.content: I wasn't very enthrilled or scared by this movie.  Maybe that's because this movie came out in the 60's and I'm living in 21st centry filled with bloody movies. reviews.review_title: The doll-faced heroine and the doll full of heroin...
reviews.content:
When a doll is stuffed by heroin, heroin becomes the stuff a big nightmare is made on, and if you think your comfortable viewer's position will get you immune to genuine fright, you've got another thing coming... or jumping.So, we have a blind woman named Suzy Hendrix, left alone in her apartment and three men who want to get the doll. How that doll got in Suzy's possession is swiftly handled like a typical Hitchcock McGuffin. How the two con-artists Talman (Richard Crenna) and Carlino (Jack Weston) accept to help a sinister black-clad sunglasses-spotting criminal named Raut (Alan Arkin) to get a hold on the doll is smoothly executed in an expositional blackmailing. And how we get to this get-the-doll premise to a harrowing thriller is the second of a three-act structure from Frederic Knott, who wrote "Dial M for Murder".Then Terence Young's nonsense directing transcended the unity of time and space and plot, making for an experience that would frighten the audiences through a vicious exploitation of theaters' darkness. The film is indeed known for its exceptional demand of minimal lighting in the theaters in order to enhance the sense of sheer terror at the climax. And yes, while experiencing it, I was wondering how it would have looked in the theater, the last scene that made me think so was the horrific shower in "Schindler's List".Remember, women were taken to the camp shower, they have heard rumors about hem being death traps, but what could they do? The door was closed and then the anticipation is worse than the ensuing situation. Of course they scream, what else could they do? Since the dawn of ages, darkness has been associated to death and terror in a way that's been rooted in our DNA. But here we get a plot where for once, darkness is synonym of life, because that's how the blind person's life is defined... and yet it doesn't make the moments in the darkness any less scary.And the whole story is based on an audacious plan that relies on the writer's creative ability in anticipating his own character's creativity. First, Suzy is the center of a plot meant to earn her trust so the three thugs can look for the doll without awakening suspicions. And progressively, she starts to realizes that something isn't right, she's capable to hear familiar footsteps or stores being opened and closed. It's a matter of time before she assembles the pieces of the puzzle, not without the help of a kid named Gloria... who lives upstairs.
The film sets the tone and the mood in an effective way, and no matter the flaws that come in the way, the ending is satisfying because we're kept at the edge of our seat, rooting for a heroine twice, because she's blind and because she's Audrey Hepburn... and because she's facing a villain who mans business although I'm not much a fan of the way Arkin played his Raut like a master of disguise, it looked too farcical for such a no-nonsense film. Anyway, after "The Miracle Worker", I wanted to stay on the 'blind' theme and watch another classic, so "Wait Until Dark" came as a natural choice.I expected another tale of damsel in distress lost in an apartment and I got that but a little more I didn't expect, a film that seems to exploit in a playful way the idea of having a blind protagonist surrounded by criminals and turn a promising gimmick into a frightening and unforgettable experience, especially during the final ten minutes. Indeed, if one must judge a thriller by its climax then Terence Young" "Wait Until Dark" ISa masterpiece.What can be blamed though is that it take a little time to build up and that the film is so cautious in not letting many loose ends that we ought to find a few glaring ones. Roger Ebert kept wondering why Suzy didn't lock the door, I saw the film carefully and I guess that one can be so distraught he might forget. I had just forgot my glasses today and have difficulty writing right now, quite fitting for the movie. But I'm not giving up easily on the film, there are a few contrivances here and there but Audrey Hepburn gives the kind of performances where she encourages our own suspension of disbelief.From the very start we can feel that she smells something fishy, too many things happen in a short span of times, two many intrusions, a cop, an old friend, but in the confusion, she seems to maintain her trust on Crenna because their interaction seems to work despite its malevolent starter, which speaks for the film's effort to maintain a realistic touch.And it is realistic from our own POV, we wander through the house enough time to get used to it, to feel the place and then like Suzy, be able to anticipate the moves and counter-attack the bad guys. The building allows her to count on the help of her neighbor Gloria and determine whom she can trust. Some users said why didn't she leave the place, well maybe because if there's one place to be blind, you're your home....Not that it says much, it all comes to the point where she realizes she must destroy all the sources of light in the film (almost)... if she's got to face a ruthless killer, let's make it a fair fight... one wouldn't believe she could pull off but "The Miracle Worker" thought me a blind and deaf person could become a writer, I can buy that a blind woman can do it. Still, the film isn't interested in the what she does but how she does and this is where it gets is spot as one of the scariest and thrilling experiences ever.Young knows how to dispose a few jump scares and taking the ultimate step by plunging the screen in full darkness. If only for that, this is an experience any movie lover should live.

reviews.review_title: One of the most tense thrill rides ever. A truly great film!
reviews.content: After watching Breakfast at Tiffany's and Roman Holiday, I saw that Audrey had talent to go with the looks and I quickly garnered a near obsession for her! Wait Until Dark may not be her most attractive role, even though she is extremely gorgeous in this film, but it is definitely one of the best performances I have ever seen by anyone. Coupled with this fantastic performance is a brilliant plot build up. The scheme put together by the men looking for the doll is very clever as, although contrived, takes full advantage of Susy's blindness. Even more clever is how Susy works out their scheme, mainly by using her heightened sense of hearing, something the men did not take in to consideration. These slow, intricate developments are fascinating to watch but most importantly, lead to a climatic ending reaching Hitchcock levels of suspense. As the title of the film suggests, you really have to wait until dark to fully appreciate how well made this film is. When Susy turns the tables on Roat (Alan Arkin) by smashing all the lights, the cliff hanger is nail biting and it isn't until the very last shot that you see who comes out on top. Hepburn is especially well cast in this role as it is very unnerving to see such an icon go through such an ordeal.As I mentioned, Audrey Hepburn's portrayal of Susy Hendrix is an all time great performance. The way she depicts being blind is very convincing; the frustration at her condition is very clear to see and her mannerisms appear perfect. This is a great role for Audrey as she often was cast in lovely films that lacked edge. This, along with Charade, packs a bit more of a punch and gives her something to grind her beautiful teeth in to. It's a shame she went on a ten year hiatus because this could have been the start of a new era in her film roles. Alan Arkin is excellent as Roat. Although he should maybe leave impersonations to someone else, he is the personification of evil and comes across very well as a ruthless crook. The lack of remorse and his apparent calmness are very effective in letting the audience know what they're dealing with. Richard Crenna also puts in a good performance as the semi likable Mike. He is charming but also very impatient with regards to the doll, the only thing that Susy appears to be ignorant on.As the film almost exclusively takes place in a flat, there is an overwhelmingly claustrophobic feel going on which does wonders with regards to the suspense build up. The director has done a great job in making Susy appear vulnerable and making you really care about what is going to happen. The low lighting levels create a very intense atmosphere that reflects the dark goings on within the film. To compliment the direction perfectly is the haunting score. The repetitive piano pounding in parts is almost numbing, as if you were losing one of your senses, and the high tempo music in the climatic finale makes it as if you can almost see what is happening even though there is no light.This is how thrillers, should be; style and substance in equally huge doses. I can not believe how little is thought of Wait Until Dark as it easily competes with many Hitchcock films that are regarded as classics. Maybe the genre was out of fashion at the time of release but it really does deserve ample praise as it kept me entertained and on the edge of my seat.

1967 film Wait Until Dark, adapted from Frederick Knott's 1966 play - and that is a considerable amount, given that it's one of the greatest movie thrillers of its generation - my first question is this: what on earth goes through Audrey Hepburn's mind when she's asked to appear in this movie? You have here a woman whose screen persona is completely built around her classy Continental elegance, whose personal life was marked by serious-minded humanitarianism, and you drop her into a horror-thriller about a heroin dealer antagonising a blind woman - it all seems so incomprehensible that Hepburn's seventeenth starring role should be such a grubby, grotty turn from all of the princesses and doe-eyed gamines and society women . Well it payed off big .
Audrey Hepburn received her fifth (and last) Oscar nomination for effectively playing a blind woman in this well-executed thriller based on the Broadway smash hit; equally good are the villains, played by the young Alan Arkin and Richard Crenna. . I would go so far as to say that Hepburn's blend of weakness and fortitude is the key ingredient to everything else in Wait Until Dark, providing exactly the correct note of nervous ambivalence that makes this such a superlative, viscerally effective thriller.

First a few minor spoilers. The Husband Sam is pretty much a jerk in this movie especially the end scene, although he is only in a few scenes I have no sympathy for him because of the way he treats his wife. And although Gloria is done well there is a scene where she throws a tantrum that to me was unnecessary and out of character. Let's move on shall we.The movie is a great example of a suspense/thriller, there is almost always some tension, but it does get a bit slow at times. The biggest amount of suspense is at the very end, and it's great, we are not sure exactly what happened until the last scene.The acting in this movie is superb, and Alan Arkin is one of the best villains I have seen in movies. Jack Weston is great as a semi-slimeball, Richard Crenna is a good actor but he always seems to be Richard Crenna even though he acts his parts beautifully. And Audrey Hepburn is quite believable as a recently blinded woman.Add this to your list of must see movies.

reviews.review_title: Excellent thriller - under another director it might have been great
reviews.content: It doesn't really matter, all things considered, that the husband is patronising and unlovable, or that the closing shot - a close-up of Hepburn as she hugs her husband in relief - says "the horrible deal is over" but not "the happy marriage may now resume".  It's Hepburn's story and he plays no role in it.  Still, if he were nicer, it could only improve matters: we'd be able to care more when the villains tell lies about him behind his back, for one thing.It DOES matter (a little) that the doll is valuable to the villains because it contains heroin.  I'm sure this "topical" reference felt like a modernising touch in 1967, but really - why bother building such elaborate schemes around a few teabags' full of a drug which any self-respectable crime syndicate will be importing by the tonne?  The mere fact that heroin is a SUBSTANCE, that there's always more of it where the last lot came from, ruins the effect.  No, some more traditional item hidden inside the doll would have made more sense: either jewels (which might be, for all we know, unique), or information (the password to a bank account, industrial secrets on microfilm, the key to a safe, some such).Perhaps I'm being harsh because I can't help making unfair comparisons with other Hepburn vehicles - ones directed by the likes of William Wyler, Blake Edwards, and Stanley Donen, which are made of finer stuff altogether.  But compare the script for this with the script to, say, "Charade" - both clever in different ways, you'd have a hard time saying for sure which is better; the tight way the story is constructed in "Wait Until Dark" is just marvellous, and the neat idea of keeping the action confined to the one place and most of the time to the one room is realised in a natural, uncontrived way.  On paper this is one of THE great thrillers.  Terence Young brings it competently to the screen, too, making sure we know the layout backwards, not making a single mistake that would allow the tension to collapse.

reviews.review_title: Everyone is Blind in the Dark
reviews.content: I was spoiled of this ending before seeing the film, but it was nonetheless thrilling watching the events unfold. Audrey Hepburn is always excellent but this time she gets to play with a different type of source material. Wait Until Dark is based on a crime thriller drama play by Frederick Knott and Hepburn plays the lead, who happens to be blind. I haven't seen many films based on blind characters, but it seems like she nailed this role. It's an electrifying Hitchcockian type film.I say that because it has all the makings of a Hitchcock film. Our lead is a woman who is quite the underdog, there is a mystery, and it nearly takes place all in one room. Alan Arkin plays the main antagonist and is quite memorable. But I think he could have used more development and screen time to make the climax even more impactful. The story is about Susy (Hepburn) who gets caught up in a drug deal unknowingly. The men will go to deep measures to secure their heroine, but Hepburn seems set on doing what's right. It has some classic intense scenes that can probably be classified as horror, and when you have a likable lead like Hepburn, it can be difficult to watch.Henry Mancini gives us the eerie score that compliments the visual thrills incredibly well. Even almost 50 years later, the film holds up extremely well. Even if the film is directed more like a play than an actual film, I thoroughly enjoyed this experience. Plus, Audrey Hepburn said 'Batman' in the movie. That just about combines two of my favorite things. Thank you for being awesome, Audrey.+Thrill ride, intense climax +Mancini's score +Holds up +Hepburn & Batman -Development on supporting characters 8.2/10

I can't overstate the importance of good actors for any horror movie.  Aside from a lack of tension and overly-flashy effects, many horror movies of today lack actors talented enough to persuade the doubtful viewer to allow themselves to be entertained by the movie.  As much as I love some classic horror movies such as Halloween, Rosemary's Baby, Alien etc. (as well as some sci-fi such as Terminator) I fall into the category of the viewer who plops a horror movie into the VCR while thinking, SCARE ME, ENTERTAIN ME, DO SOMETHING BESIDES SIMPLY TAKING MY MONEY.  I can say that Wait Until Dark accomplished those tasks.  I'll be honest I wasn't shaking in my boots, but the movie was sufficiently suspenseful that I was thoroughly satisfied when it concluded.  Such a feat is accomplished by great acting and a good storyline.  (NOTE: As much as I liked Mia Farrow in SEE NO EVIL(1971) (another movie with a blind woman in a scary situation), Audrey Hepburn certainly matched her intensity in a movie that had a more complex and sophisticated plot.)  Great Movie.

reviews.review_title: You Might Want to Keep the Lights On...
reviews.content: WAIT UNTIL DARK would, sadly, mark the last appearance of the luminous Audrey Hepburn in a film worthy of her. She would return in 1976's ROBIN AND MARIAN, which failed to score a big success, and 1979'S BLOODLINE, a major flop the poor woman should never have lowered herself to make. A couple of TV movies followed, but Hepburn's Hollywood career essentially ended with WAIT UNTIL DARK.Having said that, the lady really goes out on a high note here. WAIT UNTIL DARK is a taut, tense, high-energy thriller that has the added fillip of a single claustrophobic set; the film is based on Frederick Knott's Broadway hit, and aside from one short scene out on the sidewalk, all of the action takes place inside the Greenwich Village basement apartment of Susy Hendrix, a woman blinded about a year ago in an accident who is attending blind school and trying to adjust, and her husband Sam (Efrem Zimbalist Jr), a photographer who is supportive of her efforts at independence, sometimes too much so: he tends to nag at her a bit, and at one moment, she cries out at him, "Do I HAVE to be the world's champion blind lady?" to which he responds almost as loudly, "Yes!" We soon see that Sam has his reasons for wanting Susy to manage on her own as much as she can: a photographer's hours are somewhat unpredictable, and he never knows when he may be called away on a job. Sam has enlisted the help of their ten-year-old neighbor Gloria (Julie Herrod, the only actor from the Broadway cast to make it to the film), but there is some tension between the girl and Susy at first; Susy thinks Gloria has been moving the furniture around to confuse her, and Gloria, neglected by her mother, is somewhat sullen and takes it out on Susy.But it is not Gloria who is moving the furniture. For the apartment has already been invaded by three men: Mike Talman (Richard Crenna), one "Sergeant" Carlino (Jack Weston), and Alan Arkin as Harry Roat Jr from Scarsdale, one of the most fascinating screen villains I have ever seen.The plot revolves around a doll filled with heroin that a woman smuggled in from Montreal to New York. As the opening credits roll, the woman arrives in New York, sees someone who frightens her waiting at the terminal, and quickly hands the doll off to Sam. He ends up taking it home and then it goes missing.To reveal anything more than the basic setup would be unfair; this is a hell of a good thriller, with great performances all around by the entire cast, especially Hepburn and Arkin, who face off in a final showdown in the apartment that will literally have you jumping out of your seat.Hepburn was only thirty-nine when she made this, and looked easily ten years younger, but as a final bow, this is a film the lady should have been very proud of.

reviews.review_title: ONE OF MY ALL TIME FAVORITE FILMS IT IS A MASTERPIECE
reviews.content: That is a pretty awesome blind lady. A very well made motion picture. Wait Until Dark was an awesome movie. Audrey Hepburn's performance was outstanding. feeling so much empathy and anxiety and panic along with her...really one of the most scary movies ever. The genius of this movie is that you're absolutely terrified for her the whole time. and to think all this could have been avoided of the little girl Gloria didn't take the doll

Limited thrills and suspense in this film version of the Knott play with Hepburn playing a blind woman who is terrorized by three crooks in pursuit of a doll that has heroin inside of it. Arkin is slightly menacing as the psychotic Harry Roat, while Crenna and Weston blandly portray the other crooks. Zimbalist turns in for two or three scenes as Audrey's love interest, a photographer. Audrey was Oscar nominated, but I didn't fully buy her blind bit. The ending was too rushed and lacked excitement. Lee Remick and Robert Duvall starred in the original stage production of the play, while Mira Sorvino and the oddly cast Quentin Tarantino (as Roat) starred in the much criticized revival a year or so.

reviews.review_title: Solid Thriller with a Exciting Climax
reviews.content: Solid thriller about a blind woman who is trapped in her apartment and menaced by a group of drug dealers. Builds the suspense quite nicely, culminating in a very exciting final 15 minutes. Filmed almost entirely in one room, which is actually a asset since it emphasizes the main characters isolation.  Arkin overplays his part making his character seem almost cartoonish at times.  Hepburn is the one that makes the picture.  Her keen ability to project her characters slow realization of the terror that is out there is what really creates the tension.  Well choregraphed with creative use of lighting.

It kept me on the edge of my seat, and scared and thrilled....Audrey Hepburn is great in this role, and the story captivated me. It's not my favorite, but it's still a very good and suspenseful movie.

I watched "Wait Until Dark" for about the 12th time yesterday and found it was still a thrilling movie.  My favorite scene is when Audrey Hepburn turns the tables momentarily on the character of Harry Roat played by Alan Arkin. I won't spoil the movie for those who haven't seen it by going further.  I enjoyed Alan Arkin's performance as well as Richard Crenna, although he seemed miscast as a villain.
