reviews.review_title: Tap. TAP! TAP TAP TAP! But, pay attention.
reviews.content: This is a movie I have seen probably at least a dozen times, but I'm ashamed to admit that it's taken me that long to really understand the nuances of the 'evil plot'. For those of you who - like me - may not absorb each detail of a complicated scheme with multiple people involved -- this review is for you.When I first watched, I LOVED this movie. So, I will start by saying: even if you don't understand the scheme of the criminals, you will still find this movie captivating.It becomes much more interesting to really understand the plot, because it brings an appreciation for how much weight Susy (Audrey) carried in her role as a recently-blind woman.Facts: Susy was only recently blind a year prior to this set of events. She also found her husband AFTER she was blinded, so she theoretically has never had her sight while with him. They live in a brownstone (i think) in NYC, and he is a professional photographer. She goes to blind school.The first thing that struck me was the scene; NYC is the perfect gritty backdrop for criminals who prey on Susy and husband Sam's home as the location of one very-wanted doll. The doll in question means nothing to Susy or her husband, until it becomes so valuable that both of their lives are at stake. A side role, Gloria, is played by a talented actress who also starred in the stage version of this movie. She is the sassy - but important- little pre-teen who lives in the same building with her mom.All of this background is helpful because you'll begin to see a revolving door of criminals, with fake disguises, plus many presumed inferences that are expected of the audience.My advice is: Watch and listen from the start. Pay attention to actual names, relationship references, timelines, and motivations. Listen to each word that the bad guys say, even if it seems unimportant.Remember that Susy is not a fool.And finally, expect to appreciate that no one is an island. Even if we have all of our 5 senses and our wits, we can be outsmarted, and the least likely people to help us often do.Best aspects of this movie: the properly 60s decor, the curated wardrobe from Ms. Hepburn's own closet (for herself), the inherent hilarity of the bad guys, and several audience-shocker moments.

(some spoilers)Wait Until Dark is a wonderful suspense film, which explores different modes of sensation. Having a blind woman as the central character allowed Terrence Young lots of choices with angles and lighting. However, I believe that the sound in this film was carefully exploited as an identifying element and a tool for our blind heroine. 	Right away we are brought to the beginning of the crime and the origins of the very valuable doll. The radio heard in the background is the main audio element on the shanty apartment where the package is constructed. Through the noise we can tell the setting in somewhere in France, therefore establishing an international drug plot. The radio sets up the size of the playing field, and later the ambiguity regarding all of the major players.	Later on when Roat (Arkin) goes back into the closet, the opening of the door reveals Lisa (the doll's transporter) stuffed in a body bag, hung from a coat hanger. She is clearly dead, but her lifelessness seems to be the focus of this shot. As Roat starts to fiddle with the bag, the next cut shows Suzy in her living room listening for clues. We hear the body tumble from the hanging position with a thunderous thud. Although we do not witness the body falling, this technique creates an audio point of view. We hear (and see) what the main character does, in turn we can infer the severity of the situation. 	It is interesting to note that Hepburn's character totally relies on smell, touch and noise to comprehend and communicate. The surprise in the film is that, in many instances, information is withheld from the audience so we can appreciate the struggle this character endures. We only notice the squeak in Roat's shoe after it is mentioned, but we remember that Young used cut way shots on the shoe and Suzy's reaction before she divulged this discovery. The blinds are used as a way of communicating silently to the van across the street, but Suzy later reveals that she was suspicious of its constant use. When she finally knows that a van is outside, Suzy breaks down in terror with a sense of pity. It would seem that she almost feels sorry for herself for not knowing this element sooner. We do not expect her to feel this way, but her diligent husband might expect more from `the world's champion blind lady.'A dark, seedy thriller.*** (of ****)

reviews.review_title: Did You Know They Wanted To Kill Me ?
reviews.content: Harry Roat Jr, from Scarsdale, is a bad man who is after a doll loaded with drugs which has inadvertently wound up in the Manhattan basement apartment of Susy Hendrix, an innocent blind lady. Roat enlists some criminal associates and devises an elaborate scam to steal back the doll, but doesn't count on Susy's intelligence and resourcefulness.To paraphrase Sophie Tucker, a good villain is hard to find. Sometimes a really great villain lifts a film up and up beyond its potential (Lee Van Cleef in Il Bueno Il Brutto Il Cattivo, Rutger Hauer in Blade Runner, Martin Sheen in The Dead Zone) and Harry Roat Jr, from Scarsdale, is one of these rare breeds. Arkin captures just exactly the right mix of ruthless intelligent psychopath and heartless thug, and literally everything he says and does in this movie is both captivating and horrifying. Kudos also to Hepburn, who gets both her extreme physical and emotional performance bang on; it's her helplessness that sells the story's tension, but she's never one-dimensional or stupid. The supporting cast all fit snugly into their parts, allowing the complicated who's-fooling-who scenario and the sharply observed dialogue to flow (one of my many favourite lines is when Crenna asks Weston where Arkin is and he replies, "Who knows. Out beating up old ladies."). This is a thriller which starts slowly but methodically cranks up the pressure to boiling point as layer upon layer of horrors are piled upon poor Suzy. Henry Mancini's score ties knots in your stomach and the photography by Charles Lang (an Old Hollywood pro who shot The Cat And The Canary, Ace In The Hole, The Magnificent Seven, countless others) is nigh-on perfect. The chilling shot of Arkin's blank face with his Teashade sunglasses emerging out of the darkness as he knifes Crenna in the back and pushes him down the stairs, is for me one of the most terrifying and memorable in all cinema. Brilliantly scripted by Robert Carrington, based on a great play by Frederick Knott (who also wrote Dial M For Murder). Produced by actor Mel Ferrer, Hepburn's husband at the time; she officially retired from acting after this movie to raise a family, but subsequently made a few more film appearances. Well directed by Young - best known for directing three James Bond flicks in the sixties - with a hair-raising final twenty minutes which are amongst the most nail-biting in any movie, and should be watched with the lights out.

60s exquisite-ism. A satisfying flick. Audrey Hepburn at her high wattage best as a blind housewife up against Alan Arkin as the best, bad, heroin-seeking guy EVER. "Me topsy, you turvy." The plot will wrap you up and keep you seated firmly on the edge, that is, until... Knowing what was coming in THE scene, I turned to watch my bf's reaction instead of the screen. Worth it. He fell out of his chair. Big guy, too. Big fall. Big movie!

Wait Until Dark is a nifty little suspense film about a trio of thugs trying to trick a blind woman. It's ingenious though overly complicated, and notable for some terrific moments, most notably in the final section.Looking like a beatnik gone bad, Alan Arkin gives a love-it-or-hate-it performance as a psychopath. I really liked him, he was strange and menacing and mysterious. My girlfriend's main reaction seemed to be, "what on earth is that accent supposed to be." (I'd say outer New York or New Jersey, but who knows.)The story is convoluted and requires characters to be alternately smart and dumb, particularly Hepburn as the blind woman, who veers back and forth from obtuse and incompetent to clever and observant; sometimes all of that in a five-minute period. I was also really creeped out by her relationship with her husband. She was needy and pathetic and he seemed cold and demanding. I'm wondering if this is the result of the movie only being 90 minutes - the play was undoubtedly longer, and perhaps spent more time on the dynamics of the relationship, establishing why she grovels and why he seems borderline cruel, even in the final scene. On the other hand, maybe people were just so used to this dynamic in the '60s that it didn't seem strange back then.Overall, this is an entertaining suspense film of the sort Hitchcock made, and well worth seeing for all its flaws.

The opening sequence held my interest : A drugs courier stuffs satchels of smack into a doll and walks through an airport . This is a throwback to the days when both good and bad people could go into an airport terminal and expect to be given only the lightest of searches by airport security , no dogs sniffing around , no policemen with guns walking around the terminal in an era I've never known But that's about the start and end of anything interesting with WAIT UNTIL DARK . Billed as a suspenseful thriller and highly regarded by many people on this page I found myself wondering what all the fuss was about . Seeing as airport security was so lax wouldn't the US postal service be similar ? The dealers could easily have sent the drugs by post hence saving on hiring a courier , but I guess we wouldn't have a movie and to be honest I wouldn't have been bothered one way or the other as the plot drags at a snail's pace . The only watchable thing in the movie is Alan Arkin's beatnik villain - " yeah baby " - and he's watchable for not the best of reasons either . The 1971 British film BLIND TERROR is a much more enjoyable thriller

reviews.review_title: One of the most Hitchcockian films to not be directed by Hitchcock
reviews.content: Audrey Hepburn is such a sweet, precious concoction that it's hard to imagine her in a thriler. That is, it's hard to imagine anyone wanting to kill her. In "Charade" (a widely available hybrid romcom-thriller that epitomizes the 60s), the villains are so quirky and even cute in a Looney Tunes kind of way that you never really feel like she's in danger.In contrast, "Wait Until Dark" is a thriller that pushes that line. Audrey Hepburn plays a blind woman, Susy, who's husband becomes implicated in a drug-trafficking scheme when a doomed mule passes him a doll with a stash in it. Like a Hithcock film, "Wait Until Dark" comes with its own meaningless McGuffin. A cold-blooded criminal (a young Alan Arkin fresh off his first Oscar nomination) enlists two fellow thugs to weasel the doll out of Suzy.With Suzy's impaired sense of sight, the film is simultaneously a psychological thrill ride while maintaining a light tone as the two parties (Suzy is aided in part by an adolescent neighbor) engage in a battle of wits. The film wrings out a certain dramatic irony to the situation as we are privy to more than Suzy's point of view but she is still the character we are most emotionally attached to.Adapted from a play by Frederick Knott, director Terrence Young milks the tension through keeping the play almost entirely in her apartment.

Wait Until Dark (1967) Audrey Hepburn, Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna, Efrem Zimbalist Jr., Jack Weston, Samantha Jones, Julie Herrod, D: Terence Young. First-rate suspense classic about blinded housewife Susy Hendrix (Hepburn) being watched by a trio of criminal masterminds, led by Arkin, who are seeking a doll smuggled with heroine. They search her apartment without her knowledge in a staged police investigation. Very inventive story borrows the Master of Suspense's style and is based on the stage play by Frederick Knott. Running Time: 105 minutes. *** ½

reviews.review_title: "What If I Get Chopped Up Into Little Pieces, And Get Thrown Into The River?"
reviews.content: One of the best crime thrillers. The premise would seem to indicate a talky, claustrophobic hostage-with-hoods drama. Wait Until Dark covers that territory, but with a surprising amount of action and subtlety. Alan Arkin makes a great slimy creep as the lead crook Roat, in all his incarnations. Richard Crenna's Mike and Jack Weston's Carlino make suitably reluctant, though equally deceptive cohorts. At first it's hard to 'see' the point of having Audrey Hepburn's Susy be blind; that device turns out to be both a help and a hindrance for the criminals.Instead of meekly submitting to the criminals, Susy slowly but steadily figures out that these guys aren't her husband Sam's (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.'s) old Marine buddy, a cop, and an eccentric father and son. That they try such elaborate deceptions complicates their chances to retrieve the missing doll, but cleverly make it more plausible that she'll give it up. One thing they didn't count on was the neighbor girl Gloria (Julie Herrod) interfering, and acting literally as Susy's eyes. The fact that Gloria's had the doll for part of the time is one of those apparently meaningless events that frustrates the criminals' attempt to control everything.Susy's plan to turn the tables on these jokers is as good as their role-playing plan. Putting out all the lights in the apartment takes advantage of her blindness, plus she rigs up a nasty chemical in the potted plant. As many others have said, the long ending is chilling, incredibly tense, and visually stunning. The black-out sequences as Susy taunts the gasoline-soaked Roat with matches are eerie and wild. She's again vulnerable, as Roat, stabbed and dying, is able to lunge at her like a crazed zombie.It would seem that the criminals would've cut the phone sooner, but then they wouldn't have been able to communicate and coordinate their actions. The fact that Roat double-crosses the other two isn't surprising; they were planning the same fate for him. Since the doll could be anywhere, and in fact it's constantly moved in the course of the movie, it more or less forces a degree of cooperation between the criminals and Susy. Their little ploy to convince her that Sam is somehow mixed up with the recently murdered Lusa (Samantha Jones) is not very convincing. On the other hand, we learn that Susy hasn't known Sam long enough to know all possible skeletons in his closet, not to mention that their short romance and marriage gives Mike plausibility as Sam's old friend. Sam is kind of a jerk--he condescending to Susy--in an odd way, Mike almost seems more appealing.Some things do strain the suspension of disbelief. I see why Lisa hands the doll off to Sam; but how does Roat find out that she did? And how does he know that Sam lives in Lisa's old place? I guess he doesn't know until he goes there to find Lisa...I probably missed something. Anyway, although Gloria fits into the plot well, why doesn't Susy have her go home and call the police? The three criminals can't be everywhere in the apartment building. Despite some plot holes, Wait Until Dark is an excellent suspense thriller, unique, and well worth a bunch of viewings. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Make Sure To Watch This Classic, With The Lights Off!
reviews.content: The iconic and eternally beautiful Audery Hepburn, play's Suzy, who is recently blinded after a automobile accident,Her photographer husband played by Efrem Zimbalist, is just returned home from a trip to toronto, en route at the airport he is handed a doll, by a mysterious women, but this is no ordinary doll, it contain's a large quantity of heroin!Enter three mysterious men played by the Sympathetic Richard Crenna, the bumbling Jack Weston, and the deranged psychopath, Alan Arkin,who excel's in his exceptional role of terrorizing poor Audery Hepburn! All men have one thing in common and that is the doll! As Zimballisat goes away on an assignment, the trio using any mean's necessary one way or another want the doll, but they've got to to contend with Hepburn, who attempt's to play the thug's at their own game, Directed by the man that brought the first James Bond Flick to the screen's 'Dr No, Terence Young, Wait Until Dark, is an undeniably entertaining classic thriller that will have you literally 'jump' in it's final moment's, 'Wait Until Dark' will certainly appeal to fans of Hepburn, And Alan Arkin, It really is one of the finest thriller's ever committed to celluloid,

THe film takes a long time to get going, which wouldn't be so bad, if the characters had been drawn a little more convincingly. Crenna and Zimbalist Jr are totally wooden anyway, and the Zimbalist Jr character is not convincing as Hepburns husband-would she really love such a misogynistic arrogant man? Especially after only a year? There are many flaws in the narrative, but these are compensated by the last fifteen minutes which are very well done, and the performances of Hepburn and Arkin. T hey add a quality which the rest of film doesn't deserve, even though the scenes where Arkin impersonates two different people jar-they simply don't ring true and one wonders if the crooks would really go to all that trouble. The film should have been so much better given the premise-one wonders what Hitchcock would have done with it!

reviews.review_title: One of My Earliest Experiences of A Thriller Classic
reviews.content: 1 February 2009. I was in junior high school in the balcony of the old fashioned auditorium at the school that has since been torn down. But it was completely dark, almost pitch dark except for the faint, tiny exit signs. When the climax of this movie came up, it was completely quiet and the terror and fear was physically noticeable. The experience 40 years later still remains. This is one of those thriller classics, starring Audrey Hepburn that uses the classic techniques of music build-up, helplessness and yet mindful presence. The black and white almost made the movie more sinister and scary, the contrast between seeing and blindness almost palpable. This was one of the scariest movies I've sat through. I timeless classic along with a haunting musical score. 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Blind and Alone and Trapped in Her Apartment
reviews.content: In the Montreal airport, a woman (Lisa = Samantha Jones) carrying a doll laden with heroin packets, boards a flight to New York. In JFK airport, the woman, knowing that she is being followed by her partner in crime, hands the doll to a stranger that she met on the airplane, telling him that she will fetch it later. She intends "going into business for herself." The stranger, NY photographer Sam Hendrix (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.), takes the doll to his basement apartment, where he lives with his blind wife Susy (Audrey Hepburn). Before long Sam cannot locate the doll. So we have the setting for the story: there will be attempts to recover a lost doll stuffed with heroin.A short time after, two small-time crooks recently released from prison, Mike Talman (Richard Crenna) and Carlino (Jack Weston), are contacted by sinister Harry Roat (Alan Arkin, Jr.) to meet at Sam and Susy's apartment. When they arrive, Sam and Susy are obviously not there. After showing them Lisa's body, which he stowed inside the bedroom closet, he convinces the two to help him find the doll for $2000 each. They leave the apartment. Throughout the rest of the movie, they enter when they please. Inexplicably, the front door is rarely bolted, if ever.After Sam and Susy are introduced together, Sam has to leave on a short business strip to New Jersey. Also, Sam and Susy's neighbor Shatner leaves for the weekend. Susy is alone. The three men – Roat, Talman, and Carlino – variously attempt to deceive Susy by means of false identification, but to no avail. She of course knows nothing about the drugs. Only later do we learn that Susy's young teen neighbor who lives upstairs Gloria (Julie Herrod) – who has been paid to help Susy on errands – has "borrowed" the doll. Now Gloria can be troublesome, although she will show her usefulness later. Meanwhile, with Gloria's help, Susy sees through the motives of the three men and hides the doll. She refuses to reveal its whereabouts to Talman, but he, respecting Susy's courage, decides to give up and go away, along with Carlino.Soon the psychopath Roat kills Carlino, and intent on getting his hand on a fortune in illicit drugs, stabs Talman to death in Susy's apartment. The telephone wires having already been cut, he confronts trapped and blind Susy alone. The woman, expecting him, has evened the odds a bit by breaking all of the light bulbs and pouring a chemical into a flower pot that she will shove into his face. Her blindness has given her an advantage in darkness. Despite all of her actions, Susy is eventually overcome by Roat and allows him to take the doll after he promises not to hurt her in any way. Savoring his victory, Roat cuts open the doll and stuffs his pockets with the heroin powder packets. Meanwhile Susy arms herself with a butcher knife, just in case it is necessary. Instead of leaving quietly with his treasure, creepy Roat breaks his promise and says that he is going to take Susy into the bedroom. In the subsequent struggle, Susy stabs Roat in the stomach. He appears to die, but as Susy stumbles across the apartment, Roat leaps and causes Susy to trip. In the darkened apartment, with no light except that of the jam-opened refrigerator, Roat, pulling out the knife that was used to stab him, staggers toward Susy, intent on murdering her. In the tensest of moments, she cowers helplessly behind the opened refrigerator door, trying to pull out the electrical cord to deny Roat any light. She screams as Roat dies and police sirens are heard. Sam, Gloria, and the police rush into the apartment.The climax is as memorable as they come. No question about it, the film is indeed a nail-biter, a superior suspense drama. Lee Remick had the prominent lead role in the 1966 NY Broadway stage play of the same name (which this much younger writer attended in the front row). Attractive and classy, Audrey Hepburn looked younger than her years. The dearly-loved Dutch-English performer was a master at playing vulnerable women. Note Hepburn's performance with Cary Grant in "Charade" four years earlier. Before that the multi-lingual actress starred in such films as "Roman Holiday" (1953), "Sabrina" (1954), "The Nun's Story" (1959), "Breakfast at Tiffany's" (1961), and "My Fair Lady" (1964). She received an Academy Award nomination for her role as Susy Hendrix; she had won the Award for "Roman Holiday." Italian-American Richard Crenna was known for his TV work, especially as Lucas McCoy in "The Real McCoys" (1957-1963). His work outside of TV included his role as Trautman in the "Rambo" movie series. Efrem Zimbalist Jr., who is nearly a century old, began his movie career as Tony Monetti in "House of Strangers" with Edward G. Robinson. He starred in the TV series "77 Sunset Strip" (1958-1964), and "The F.B.I." (1965-1974). Multi-talented Alan Arkin, who had several Academy Award nominations, finally won for his performance in "Little Miss Sunshine" (2006).

A woman smuggles drugs from Canada. She uses a doll for the same. She hands the doll over to a person in the airport for safekeeping. There are three people who are looking for the doll. The man is Audrey Hepburn's husband. She is a recently blinded woman. Her husband has to go out on some pretext. The three goons come up with a diabolical plan to get the doll from her. Will they succeed? This is one of the most gripping and original movies I have seen recently. The story twists and twists and the viewer is totally mesmerized. Alan Arkin who plays the ring leader is chilly as a cunning murderer who is hellbent on getting the doll. He is ably assisted by Richard Crenna. But the movie belongs to Audrey HepBurn. As the blind woman, she is absolutely brilliant. Her mannerisms are spot on and the credit for this should also go to the writer who has written her part so well. The end sequence is terrifying and brilliant. the best part is that the movie is 45 years old but still feels refreshingly new. 4 out of 5 for Wait Until Dark. Don't wait. watch it ASAP.

As a teenager, I am easily drawn to thrillers like "The Faculty" and "Disturbing Behavior."  It's not likely for me to be eager to see a movie like this one.  My mom, who hates the thrillers that are out these days, suggested I watch "Wait Until Dark" with her.  It was on TV and she told me that it was a thriller that scared her when she was my age.  Knowing the movie wouldn't have the action packed sequences like "Scream", I sarcastically said to my mom "It must be an exciting thriller."  And indeed it was.  In fact I think I enjoyed it more than my mom did. This movie has a well written script.  I bought Hepburn's blindness. I especially liked Arkin's performances with the three different characters. I also thought Arkin's smooth talk was a nice touch as well as his sunglasses.  Gloria was a good comic relief from the suspense that built-up inside me; I still can't get over that "girl scout cookie" line.  I never get tired of seeing this movie whenever it airs on AMC.  They definitely don't make this kind of movie anymore and I wished they did. There were about 2 confusing scenes. And at times, Hepburn would get too worked up in being blind, that she'd have a delayed reaction on her hearing as well. But there is no doubt that she did an incredible performance. I don't think I have yet seen a thriller that was so smart, sly, and sassy as this one.  "Wait Until Dark" is a thriller with class -- something thrillers these days are missing out on.

The set-up of this movie is pretty interesting- a group of criminals (led by the extremely nasty Harry Roat - Alan Arkin, in a terrible performance) have to find a dope-filled doll which accidentally ended up in the hands of a young woman.  The catch is, she's blind- so as long as they can get her alone, and concoct a story, they can look all they want for the doll.  It was originally a play, and boy is that obvious- all the action takes place inside one apartment.  Actually, all the action is locked inside one apartment.  There is a definite claustrophobia to this film; its essentially just a series of people going in and out of the place, enacting a ludicrously overcomplicated plot to find the doll.  The movie is basically relentless exposition, and the only thing that staves off boredom is the knowledge that Something bad is going to happen.  No script could get away with such tedium and not deliver a payoff, and this one doesnt.  The infamous "shocker" ending so many people talk about is nowhere to be found. I imagine the ending would be much more effective live onstage, though I cant imagine sitting through the entire thing in a theater.In any event, Audrey Hepburn's performance is very very good, as is Richard Crenna as another of the criminals; but Arkin's misses the mark completely. And noone is helped by the amateurish script, which is long on plot machinations but short on realistic dialogue.  Really, the only good scenes are the first- a brilliantly conceived scene in which Hepburn walks around her bedroom not realizing there is a dead woman hanging in her closet- and the last, in which Hepburn and Arkin do battle in near-darkness (lit only by the refrigerator light.)  But again, I was sorely disappointed that the payof- promised by the film's very atmosphere- never came.  (I would have been much more interested if Hepburn's husband turned out to be one of the criminals, and he killed her after the police left.)

I had great expectations from this movie, especially seeing the high rating and the actors' names. What I got instead proved to be an extremely naive "thriller/mystery" that left me with more questions than answers. For example, why wouldn't she just give them the damn doll?!! Or why send the little girl in the park to look for her husband so that he can come with the police instead of just sending her directly to the police station? Even the way the criminals tried to convince her to give up the doll is not at all convincing? What happened to good old physical methods that are so common in today's movies? And so on and so forth, I could just go on and on forever. Disappointed, that's what sums it.

reviews.review_title: How Did This Film Get By Us?!
reviews.content: The surface of Wait Until Dark presents an emotional, becoming performance from Audrey Hepburn, a wonderfully entertaining villain by the great Alan Arkin, the perfect urban atmosphere distinguished in 1960s cinema, and very tense and extensive scenes of suspense. Also, on the surface of Wait Until Dark is a glaring mess of a script. How did the laughable, almost Pythonesque logical errors of this movie whisk by us? Imagine if the Mona Lisa turned out to be smiling with her mouth open all these years and we missed it? That's how my last viewing of Wait Until Dark felt. I felt stupid. And that's what we all are, because we all loved this film when we first saw it. But watch it a second time. Ask yourself the following questions.Why, when this woman is blind, do these men need to physically disguise themselves? These men, these hoodlums, try to convince Hepburn through a laborious scheme that her husband has been implicated in a crime and the only way to protect him is to surrender the doll which secretly contains heroin that they are striving to get, so why do they disguise themselves in any way at all? She is blind. If they took care of the doll situation quickly by knocking on the door, subduing her, finding the doll and leaving, she wouldn't be able to implicate them no matter how hard she tried. Once again, she is blind. If you wear gloves and don't leave any fingerprints, she hasn't a chance. The two hours this film spends on their scheme is two hours wasted. The young girl of course can't identify them because of their disguises, but then again what would she see anyway if the thugs took care of the situation in the way I just explained? It would take a few minutes and they'd have their doll!Also, the staging of this film is very laughable. For instance, near the beginning, there is a stand-off between Alan Arkin and both Richard Crenna and Jack Weston. They grab blunt objects throughout the room like chairs, bottles, and tripods. Crenna finds it to be even more threatening by swinging a camera by its strap in the air as if it were a lasso or a mace. Come on. Is this West Side Story? Or no. Is this the Batman series with Adam West and Burt Ward? The actors are horribly uncomfortable in this scene, and the scene has zero effect. There is another instance in this film of a couple of scenes where people walk into the apartment already talking to whom they expect to be in it without even setting eyes on it and when they do witness the room after walking into it, they are taken aback by something. Do any of you readers walk into a room blasting your voice before you've even opened the door more than a crack anyway?Wait Until Dark may be directed and acted with assurance, as if it were a seamless thriller, and the climax is actually quite a breathtaker whether you realize the gaping Godzilla footprints in the plot and staging, but why has this film, and the play it's based on, gone on to gain notoriety and acclaim? Are these glaring, screaming flaws actually hiding in plain sight?

From the very first minute you start watching 'Wait Until Dark', you know that something is going to fail miserably. The opening shot is just fabulous, in which Samantha Jones leaves her downtown Montreal place with a dope-filled little doll, intending to smuggle it to New York. After we hear Henry Mancini's eerie title tune, and we are already in New York, we are certain that something, is indeed, going to go wrong for one of the characters. Jones sees a mean looking, scenery-chewing, cool ol' Alan Arkin watching her ... she runs to this man that she met on the airplane, and gives him the doll, bumbling some senseless excuse, and runs off to encounter her cruel destiny... That's when we meet Jones's ex-partners in crime, con-men Weston and Crenna, going to this New York apartment in St. Luke's Place, thinking they will meet her again - but they meet Arkin, instead, who is eager to find the doll and will stop at nothing to obtain it. Both are invited by Arkin to work for him, in finding the doll. They accept, only to find that that was not Samantha's place at all, that was the apartment of the man in the airplane - to whom Samantha gave the doll away - and his blind wife Audrey, and Samatha was dead inside the couple's closet! Weston and Crenna try to escape, but Arkin blackmails them into doing the job, since their finger-prints were all over the place. So, they quickly concoct a complicated plot to make Suzy give the doll away, while her husband's at Asbury Park, working. What follows is a gathering of great performances, and a series of truly frightening moments, building up to the shocking, nail-biting, right-up-the-wall driving climax. After it, you will just want to to light a cigarette, roll over and fall asleep... listening to Mancini's gentle love theme, 'Wait Until Dark'...

reviews.review_title: Great choice for a weekend night!
reviews.content: Wait Until Dark (1967) is a thriller about a recently blinded woman Susy Hendrix (Audrey Hepburn). She is learning to live with her new lifestyle in her and her husband's apartment. One day when Susy's husband Sam Hendrix (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.) returns from his commute, he unintentionally ends up being a drug courier. When Sam goes to another trip and leaves Susy alone, the drug criminals start to seek the drug load. All they know is that the drugs are hidden inside a doll. The leader of the gang (Alan Arkin) starts making up disguises and different characters to get to Susy's apartment. The only help Susy's getting is from a little girl next door, Gloria (Julie Herrod).The film's milieu is the apartment in New York, where Susy lives in. She can't see anything, but she knows the place, which gives her an advantage. But then, the criminals have their sight, which gives them an advantage. The whole movie builds around the blindness of Susy. The criminals wouldn't be able to fool her, if she wasn't blind. All the scenes about this were brilliantly built. The director of many Bond films, Terence Young achieved to bring a lot of sympathy to the milieu as Audrey Hepburn did to her character.You can't call the plot the most original one out there. A lot of movies have used blindness as a way to bring sympathy to the character. Usually other senses like hearing, are stronger with these characters, for example Daredevil (2003). But still I found this the best "blindness-film" I've seen. It's well written, directed and acted, it's about all an entertaining film needs. The excitement is built brilliantly as we follow Susy's attempt to survive. Wait Until Dark's suspense grows until the final duel, (where the audience actually gets blind as well) which is one of the most unforgettable ones in the history of cinema!So if you're looking for an exciting thriller, this is a really good choice. Even that it has its minor flaws, which I don't even care to mention, it holds your interest much better than thrillers of today do. Perhaps the content of the film could be a little trickier or sophisticated, but it can't even be compared with the garbage you see from Hollywood today.7.5/10 High class entertainment! I would give it 7.5/10 but IMDb doesn't allow that. You won't be disappointed with this.

Audrey Hepburn is a doll in this movie,and then there's the other {lethal} doll to consider.And consider we shall,being the focal point and core of story.Let me begin by saying that I find this to be among THE best thrillers of all time.It gave me the jitters when I originally saw back in the 60',and still does.Credit the penetrating and piercing music that scorches and scores the background of almost every scene,with such a probing yet simple killer lullaby.Just hearing that simple melody gets my attention.It is perfectly placed and utilized within movie,and adds greatly to intensity of upcoming drama. The story basically centers around a recently blinded lady living in Grenwich Village and a missing doll that becomes the hunt for a group of unsavory individuals.The doll ,which is very valuable-having stiched inside a much sought-over recent shipment of heroine.The kind to kill for. In the hunt are 2 almost world-weary mutt and jeffish characters in the form of Richard Crenna and Jack Weston,wonderfully paired together as thieves who just so happen to pick wrong apartment for looting job.And along comes the never better cast and arch villian of sorts to render his interpretation of how to proceed with action and how to offer up con game for thrill of the hunt.None other than Alan Arkin,cast against type and totally in control of situation and circumstance of his character and beyond.Whereas Crenna plays a believably concerned and somewhat compassionate thug,and Weston a street-wise and untrusting co-hort to Crenna,Arkin steals the show.Arkin is diabolical,cunning,clever and manages to outwit and out act with a snidely dervish sense of self,never felt from him since.His Scarsdale toughness and devil may care pitch to nasal voice ,gives an abundant meanness and sociopathic quality to character.Hepburn is not far behind in creating a character that evokes a rapid and intense following to.She,very believably creates pathos and inner charm from her dissability and opportunity to exploit,for our instruction and our acting appreciation.The viewer really develops a concern for her character in all its vunerability and ease of access. Since virtually all of the action centers around coming's and going's of apartment and builds with each new developing scene,we start to feel her predicament,more and more. With a cat and mouse plot that ravels and unravels right before our eyes,we are more than privvy to things that even our heroine's # 1 blind lady can neither see but can still feel,having enough senses to know when but not exactly where,that danger lurks.And danger is the name of this tense,nail-biting thriller,sure to envelop one with a menacing sense of blind accuracy.Or hopefully so.  5 out of 5 star  or 10/10 for an unparalleled look into the eye's and mind of fear.Dig Daddio's.

Perhaps this was plausible back in the innocent 60s, but now there's just too much stretching of credibility for this movie to be effective. It's hard to be seriously frightened when what the bad guys are doing is impossible to believe.Would real drug dealers go to such lengths for what appears to be perhaps a quarter of a kilo of heroin, street value $20,000, tops? Would serious bad guys engage in elaborate measures, including costumes and play-acting, in an attempt to fool Susie into revealing the location of the doll? In real life, one of them would put a knife to her throat in scene one, and that would be that.Other things just misfire. Would a bad guy intent on terrorizing Susie splash gasoline all around, and then light a match, virtually assuring self-immolation just to scare her? For that matter, how many New Yorkers would leave a front door unlocked, with a note, no less, telling anyone who comes by that the door is unlocked, come on in? That's how Mike and Carlino get in so easily at the start, and how plausible is it that Carlino, instead of participating in the search for the doll, raids the refrigerator and lazily fixes himself a sandwich? That's the weakness of this movie, in this modern era: it's so implausible that it's not convincing, and hence isn't particularly frightening. We know much more, I'm afraid, about drugs and drug dealing and drug dealers, than we did in 1967.
Keeps you on the edge of your seat. A definite must watch for Hepburn fans. Audrey as usual is beautiful and charming. Ending is a brilliant shocker.

The story was dumb, and the acting was annoying.The premise was interesting with a storyline that evolved over time. But there were so many holes in the plot it was like watching swiss cheese be made - and just as unexciting.The acting was flat. Richard Crenna, never a major actor, had the one expression on his face. Arkin wore John Lennon glasses to look cool. Audrey Hepburn was just plain irritating. The best acting came from the young girl - she was the only believable character.The ending was the silliest part of it all "Throw me the matches" it had me wondering why I had wasted my time in staying to the end.

Terence Young directed this taut thriller based on a stage play that stars Audrey Hepburn as Suzy Hendrix, recently blinded and married to a man(played by Efrem Zimbalist Jr.) who has unknowingly come into possession of a doll filled with heroin given to him by a young woman at an airport because she feared arrest. Trouble is, three crooks(played by Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna, and Jack Weston) are after the heroin, which is worth a fortune, and so begin an elaborate scheme to search her apartment for the doll without her knowing it, though she also doesn't know that the young woman was murdered, and is hanging wrapped in her closet... Well-directed and acted thriller overcomes its exploitive premise by building believable characters and palpable suspense, especially in the heart-stopping climax.

I first saw this movie as a kid and nearly everyone in the theater screamed when Alan Arkin pulled that crazy Jack-in-the-Box stunt (if you want to know what I mean, watch the movie.) This is a very taut, suspenseful, frightening movie. Arkin's portrayal of the evil sadistic psychopath, Harry Roat, Jr., has yet to be beat (Anthony Hopkins' Hannibal Lector does come close, though.) Roat has always reminded me of an insane, murderous '50s version of Jerry Lewis. Even his voice is frightening!

reviews.review_title: A Great Premise, with some Execution Flaws
reviews.content: A good thriller with a fantastic premise, and a few flaws. Basically, a blind woman comes into possession of a doll, which is stuffed with heroin that the bad guys want to get back. Audrey Hepburn is the star of this film; she combines her customary class and beauty with an immediately believable performance as a blind woman. All the little movements/motions she does help make her blindness seem real; I'm almost convinced she wore opaque contacts for the filming; it's that good. The plot (having a blind woman defeat the bad guys by being brave/clever) is pretty original, and would have been great in the hands of someone like hitchcock. Unfortunately, most of the other actors fall short; it's not bad acting, but next to Hepburn they just seem ordinary. Another thing that pulls the movie down is how quickly Hepburn's character falls for the scheme of the bad guys (before she realizes who they). She lets them into her life way to trustingly/easily, and it pulled me out of the film. Otherwise, very enjoyable.

Even with a spoiler alert, this is one thriller that will be ruined for a first time viewer if too much is said about the plot, so, being the total blabbermouth that I am, I will try to steer clear of plot discussion and focus on other aspects that I find interesting. Written by Frederick Knott ("Dial M for Murder") and directed by Terence Young of early James Bond fame, all of the gripping suspense occurs almost entirely within the very limited confines of a basement apartment in Manhattan's Greenwich Village. The high tension is enhanced by Henry Mancini's musical score, which generates much apprehension.Opening the film in frigid Montreal at the height of winter could not have been a mere accident. Immediately, the tone of cruel, unforgiving harshness within nature itself is established, which serves as a prelude to the cold hostility of the arch villain, played brilliantly by Alan Arkin, who dominates the action that follows. I felt chilly from the start, and the wintry atmosphere provides the perfect backdrop to Mr. Roat's icy demeanor.Roat's brutality is immediately offset by the vulnerability and gentility of his victim, Susy Hendrix, played superbly by Audrey Hepburn. I had read that Lee Remick, another favorite of mine, played Susy in the Broadway play, winning a Tony. As good as Hepburn is as Susy, I regret missing Remick on stage in this role because I can imagine her portraying the victim with just a touch of sassy Laura Manion in "Anatomy of a Murder", only one of many memorable performances by Ms. Remick, who was taken from us far too soon.Arkin and Hepburn were assisted very well by an excellent supporting cast, including Richard Crenna, Jack Weston, Julie Herrod, and Efrem Zimbalist Jr. As someone who grew up with 1950's and 60's television, I was very surprised by Crenna's very serious dramatic skills a year earlier in "The Sand Pebbles" and again here as the reluctant, amateur thug who may have been falling in love with his attractive victim. Herod as Susy's nerdy but brave teenage neighbor is endearing and often overlooked in the reviews here. It's no mystery that she was picked to repeat her Broadway role.When I watched this film recently on tcm, the female host and female guest together strongly condemned the character of Sam (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.) as being inhumanly cruel to his blind wife, placing a special emphasis on her alleged victimization by him. I didn't see that at all. I think that Sam's devotion to Susy motivated his demanding toughness in teaching her how to cope as a recently blinded individual living in the harsh environment of Manhattan, a place that can be exceptionally cruel and unforgiving even to sighted persons regardless of their gender. Unfortunately, I know this from years of personal experience.Hopefully, this notorious blabbermouth didn't ruin a very suspenseful film that can very easily be destroyed by too much information. With an abundance of caution, I still clicked "spoiler alert", just in case.

What a film!! You sit glued to your seat as the film moves along. The beginning lets you get familiar with Hepburn, her situation(newly blind), and the people around her. Bits of pieces of a sinister web is slowly unraveled and then, BAM!, you're in it. Hepburn gives a brilliant performance(as always) and really makes you believe she is blind. She is a her most beautiful here, but she is anything but vulnerable. She fights for her life. Alan Arkin is fantastic as the creep who cares nothing for human life, just his lust for money. The rest of the cast if great as well. It all falls into place, piece by piece. Never too slow or too fast, it goes by at just the right pace. This is as good or even better than anything of it's kind today.Why not try "Charade" with Audrey Hepburn and Cary Grant. Not as serious but sepenseful and funny.

I'm bothered by film characterizations of people that aren't reasonably realistic when the movie purports to be realistic. In this movie, all seemed close enough to be almost reasonably possible. The 2 ex-cons, recently released from prison, were a little over the top (i.e., too gifted, too far from bumbling) in their detail and improvisations. And the little girl's (Gloria's) initial temper tantrum didn't fit, IMO, with all of her other reasonable behaviors. But, I easily brushed aside those small nit-picks and thoroughly enjoyed it.Suzy (Hepburn) was great as the recently blind wife struggling to adapt to living in a sighted world. And I suspect our natural empathy for her struggle in adapting to being blind, let alone being manipulated by the 3 criminals, very much multiplies and heightens our response. This is a VERY realistic thriller; very gripping.GREAT movie!!

reviews.review_title: Shocked by insensitivity of husband, Sam
reviews.content: I probably saw the movie when it first came out, or shortly afterward, and maybe once again in the late 1990's. Then, I watched it in high definition last night, 16 November 2009. On this viewing, I came away with a clear distaste for the insensitivity of Sam toward Suzy's blindness, to the point that I actually felt disgust for him. At the end, when he gets home to find his wife alive with two dead men in the house, having survived beyond all odds, he actually makes HER walk to HIM!!! That was too much for me. I didn't like Sam's attitude all the way through the movie, but the end was the last straw.Perhaps his role in being so hard on her was to prepare her for the ordeal with the criminals. He probably gets partial credit for her ability to be tough in the face of disaster. There was likely some such purpose to his character, in order to make Suzy's manner believable.I actually visited IMDb.com tonight to see if other posters shared my sentiments, and no one seems to; this wasn't brought up in any of the several comments that I read.In spite of this, I also share most of the good sentiments from other posts. Wait Until Dark is a fabulous movie.

reviews.review_title: A Brilliant Film from a brilliant actress
reviews.content: I recently watched this film late night when I couldn't sleep, and after only a few minutes, I was completely hooked.Audrey Hepburn was brilliant in it, and I think the character of Susy is a brilliant role model for all blind, or recently blind people. Richard Crenna was terrifying, and had me on the edge of my seat for most of his scenes. I also thought that Julie Herrod was a very good actress, despite her age. The whole storyline was very clever, and very gripping. The ending was especially outstanding.I liked how most of the movie was based in the same place, it made the film feel especially tense.I'd love to see this film again, and I'd recommend it to anyone.

reviews.review_title: WAIT UNTIL DARK might not be the year's best, but not deserves all the backlash either
reviews.content: Our Beloved Audrey Hepburn's last Oscar-nominated performance, a rare genre piece in her filmography, WAIT UNTIL DARK officially bookends her salad days with a sterling turn into a terrorised victim in this Terence Young's almost one-basement-apartment-confined thriller, based on Frederick Knott's play.Susan Hendrix (Hepburn), became blind in a car accident one year earlier, now lives with her newly-espoused photographer husband Sam (Zimbalist Jr.) in NYC . Their life is quite placid, Susan goes to the blind school to adopt her new life pattern, while Sam is engaged in work, little they know, a doll sealed with cocaine is in their possession, just because Sam implausibly accepts it from the request of a complete stranger, a sultry blonde Lisa (Jones) in the airport when he travels back from Montreal. And more implausibly, Sam not only doesn't rise any suspicion towards the item, when Lisa wants it back, he even forgets its whereabouts.Soon Lisa is dispatched by her partner-in-crime Roat (Arkin) for trying to pocket all the smuggled cocaine, and he gangs up with Mike (Crenna) and Carlino (Weston), Lisa's former associates, two small-time gangsters, together they deploy a scheme to deceive the poor blind Susan into giving up the doll. One day, when Sam is away from an assignment in New Jersey, Mike pretends to be a friend of his and visits Susan, and gets her trust by being amiable and polite, then Roat stages a scene to implicate that Sam is in liaison with the dead Lisa, and Carlino's fake sergeant also shows up, all three manage to convince Susan, the doll is the key evidence can incriminate Sam with Lisa's death, so as that she can hand it to them. But, the core problem is Susan also has no idea where is the fricking doll! Until, in the midpoint of the taut narrative, it reappears in the house and it is Gloria (Herrod), a girl lives upstairs, who takes it and just in time to return it in the critical moment.After unwisely informing Mike she has the doll, Susan put her own safely in the danger especially when she realises all these three uninvited visitors are actually in the same league to retrieve the doll, how can she fight against them? Numerously missing the chance to ask help from the police, after wisely sending Gloria to meet Sam in the station, she finds out the telephone line has been cut off, so her life is hanging by a thread. Luckily there is a silver lining under the desperate situations, which is the ill feeling among the three criminals, Mike and Carlino never trust the cunning Roat, but the latter turns out to be even more insidious and callous than they can ever imagine. Eventually, it advances into a face- off between Roat and Susan, where an edge-of-the-seat episode of battling in the darkness makes Susan our reluctant heroine in the end.The film gathers some strong dissonance of its glaring dramatic license, which tempers real-life authenticity in favour of its theatrical manipulation (all the why doesn't she lock the door complain, why she doesn't call the police or ask Gloria to call the police?, etc.). Most obviously is that blind people don't need light, but what is behind her decision to light up matches during the confrontation in the dark is truly baffling. Yet cinema is the art where vision is its most direct receptor and lightning is one integral part, audience cannot stand a long-spell of pitch black while all the happenings are sheer unseeable. Although, in the climate of experimental cinema, it would be an innovative attempt to defy our usual viewing habits.Be that as it may, Hepburn's acting alone is worth your ticket, seldom seen in such a terrified state out of her comfort zone, not to mention she nails a competent emulation of a blind person. Undeniably, there is a morbid thrill to watch those top-notch actresses being put into a victimised cul-de-sac (one major reason why we love WHAT EVER HAPPENED TO BABY JANE? 1962), is it a natural inclination? I hope so. Also, a convincing victim needs an equally relentless perpetrator, Arkin, only in his second film, is mesmerisingly menacing and utterly abhorrent to watch, a brilliant villain makes one wish there would never be anyone like him, as in reality, Susan would have no chance to survive in his merciless hands. Crenna's Mike, brings a whiff of conscience when he becomes more emotionally invested in his role-playing, not an out-and-out scoundrel, but all the same, has no chance to become the hero who saves the beautiful girl.Immensely entertaining, a great career-turn for Ms. Hepburn, which reminds us how great if she would take on more diversified roles in her mature years, trademark score from Henry Mancini, WAIT UNTIL DARK might not be the year's best, but not deserves all the backlash as well.

reviews.review_title: A riveting performance by a great actress.
reviews.content: This would have been a very forgettable Class B movie without Audrey Hepburn.  Her unbelievable acting skill turned it into one of the great movies of all time.  I can't recall a single performance by any other actor or actress that approached what she did here.

reviews.review_title: Audrey Hepburn Leaping in the 'Dark' Makes for an Exceptionally Tense Thriller!
reviews.content: Terence Young's Wait until Dark, based on Frederick Knott's gimmicky stage play, is as an exceptional suspense drama - a perfect example of how mood, atmosphere, music, and direction can overcome plot contrivances.The plot lurks around Suzy Hendrix (Audrey Hepburn, in a superior performance), a recently blinded NYC housewife whose husband Sam is determined to make "the world's champion blind lady" out of her. Although she can handle most of her daily chores alone, she still requires some help from Gloria, the dorky pre-teen girl who lives upstairs. Unbeknownst to her, Sam has accidentally played into the hands of heroin-smuggling mole who plants a dope-loaded doll in his possession. It doesn't take long for Suzy to get herself in trouble when a group of con men grease their way into her apartment in an elaborate plot to locate the doll. Two of them are merely petty con-men, but their employer Harry Roat (Alan Arkin who is unbelievably creepy) is a sinister monster. From there on, the movie ruthlessly tightens the screws of tension, all leading up to the nail-biting climax, as Roat and Suzy come face to face in her pitch-dark apartment.The film makes little effort to overcome its origins as a play, as the majority of the action takes place in Suzy's apartment. Though some of the more contrived elements of Knott's play are still intact here, Terence Young's presentation of Suzy's cloistered surroundings trumps the script's far-fetched tendencies as he manages to create a paradoxical environment of civilization devoid of human life. Also, Young makes the smart decision of setting his thriller inside a basement apartment, the cave-like arches of which have the unsettling effect of positioning Hepburn in a nondescript underground (the windows only look out on the feet of passersby, emphasizing Suzy's disconnect from her neighborhood). Terence Young's remarkable ability to create a believable oppressive locality in Wait until Dark obscures plot holes and irrationalities right up to the film's extended final showdown. By the time Suzy realizes she's completely and hopelessly alone in her apartment, the cumulative effect of Hepburn's palpable desolation and Arkin's ruthlessness, combined with Henry Mancini's overpoweringly harrowing score, bring the film to a justly celebrated climactic bacchanalia, complete with one of suspense cinema's first and most effective shock leaps.Once seen, Wait until Dark will never be forgotten. But be wary if you watch it alone. In fact, watch it with someone who likes to scream!

This is the best film I have ever seen! It's extremely suspenseful, and a part near the end made me scream bloody-murder and go from lying down to jumping straight up! Better than any Hitchcock movie! Audrey Hepburn plays a blind lady who is being harrassed by some criminals looking for a drug-stuffed doll. This is truly a GREAT movie!

reviews.review_title: turn off the lights and watch it tonight
reviews.content: This is one of the greatest thrillers and movies of all time, plus it shows the acting and directing ranges of all the people who participated in making it.  Terrence young-who was better known fro directing two James Bond films-and the cast, who are better known for being in romantic comedies, show they can also perform a straight thriller.The plot is simple: would-be heroin dealers harass a blind woman looking for a heroin filled doll in her apartment while the husband is away.  Hepburn isn't a hot teenage bimbo, naive housewive, or other such annoying character we would all care less about being done away with (as is the theme in a lot of the annoying thrillers of today).  She's a happily married woman-not fiercely independent nor overly reliable on her husband (unlike most horror lambs for slaughter)-who is trying to cope with her recent loss of sight, which more or less forces her to trust other people.  The antagonists aren't the one-dimensional slashers of today and show they can be creeps and jerks without also having to be perves (another setback of contemporary youth-obsessed Hollywood) and one of them (Crenna) is sypathetic from time to time.Young's direction and Manicini's score heighten the suspense emphasizing the cold, darkness, isolation, and claustorphobia Suzy (Audrey) feels in her predicament.  And the writing is also superb as every thing we deem insignificant-there's no back door, the neighbor left for the weekend, Sam telling Suzy to figure out for herself how to use the refrigarator-comes back to haunt us.This movie will stick with you, the climax most of all.

Wait Until Dark should be on the top #250. Great cast, great story, great direction, perfect movie from beginning to end. won't spoil it for you, but it's a film from 1967, so therefore unlike all the company products that pretend to be movies (e.g the avengers, dark knight, crap superhero movie part 9), it's a real movie. Watch it, now!

reviews.review_title: How To Build Tension In One Room With Nothing Fancy 101
reviews.content: It's pretty obvious Wait Until Dark was adapted from a play. The setting is basically one room, in a tiny apartment, and even filmed, little to nothing else happens outside this room. This actually benefits the film, it makes the action that much more claustrophobic and gives it a great sense of space and awareness of audience expectations based on their keen sense of where things are in relation to everyone else.The film builds to a pulse-pounding finale. Expertly shot and staged, with top-notch acting from both Audrey Hepburn (who in other parts of the film I thought may have been overacting a bit, or at least "stage" acting too much) and Alan Arkin (man is he good in this. Those glasses and his voice...).

This movie is one of the best movies I have ever seen.  The great thing about it is that you know what is going on the whole time, and you are so anxious for the victim to finally figure it all out!  It keeps you on the edge of your seat.  Audrey Hepburn does a great job playing a blind woman.  As the movie progresses you begin to feel more and more sorry for her!  This is a great movie and I would recommend it to anyone!

reviews.review_title: Be Sure To Leave A Light On
reviews.content: Wait Until Dark is based of the play by Frederick Knott and follows the same plot for the most part. Two small time con artists are called on by a mysterious man named Harry Roat to help him find a doll filled with heroin. It's inside a small apartment which belongs to a man named Sam Hendrix and his wife Susy(played by Audrey Hepburn). Sam is going away on a business trip leaving Susy alone in her apartment. The con men try to convince Susy that her husband is involved in an illegal drug trade. Any ordinary woman might be able to see through these men's lies. But Susy is not ordinary... she's blind. She begins to suspect what the men are telling her isn't the truth and her suspicions grow as she is able to hear them searching her apartment and can hear the footsteps of Harry Roat even when he is pretending to be someone else. The only company she has is a little girl named Gloria and soon the men begin to loose their patience and try to find the doll by force. Susy must fend for herself and level the playing field by turning off all the lights in her apartment. But what happens when she's left alone with the most dangerous of them all?Wait Until Dark is a brilliant suspense film. What makes it work is that most of it is set in a small apartment and there's only a few shots of the outside neighborhood. This makes you feel trapped inside the house much like Susy. The casting is great as well. In whatever role Audrey Hepburn plays the audience will automatically love her. This makes us care more about her character and make us down right terrified due to the position that she's in. The man who steals the show is Alan Arkin in his role as Harry Roat. He does several tactics to scare Susy such as brushing a piece of cloth against her face and pulling her neck using a cane. It's quite heinous. The best part of the film comes at the end, where all the lights have been broken by Susy and we're forced to imagine what is going on in the dark.All in all, this is a great suspense movie. Don't be surprised if you have to sleep with a light on after finishing this.

Like many others, I first saw WAIT UNTIL DARK as a young teenager and it freaked me out.   My wife and I bought the film a couple of years back and have viewed it with several friends who have all loved it.   Without exception everyone is amazed at how smart the character of Suzy is.There's a lot of suspense to the film and a real concern for the characters, except for Suzy's stupid husband "Sam"  Sam seemed to have no compassion for his wife.  What a goof. Too bad Suzy didn't get together with Mike's character!!The acting by the rest of the cast was great (Audrey was nominated for an Oscar) although the young actress who played Gloria never acted again.Great Film to watch with a group.

Frederick Knott wrote two well-plotted thrillers for the stage both of which wound up on screen. Dial M For Murder wouldn't work today dependent as it is on telephones being in a fixed place in the home; Wait Until Dark is still feasible but despite a nominal 'opening out' it still betrays its stage origins being largely confined to one room. At the same time things which don't matter/wouldn't be noticed in the theatre stand out like sore thumbs on film. For example Hepburn lives in the heart of Manhattan yet anytime the camera ventures outside her apartment - day OR night - there is no traffic in the street, yet miraculously the moment Efrem Zimbalist steps into the street - having been lured away by the bad guys - a cab comes around the corner. Apart from these cavils the suspense builds reasonably well and Audrey Hepburn is a masterly choice for a female in danger as more than half the world, both sexes, was in love with her and empathised with her plight. The trio of heavies are competent without being memorable and it's a good watch.

***SPOILERS*** With her partner in crime Louie, Jean Del Val, stuffing a doll full with packets of heroin fashion model Lisa, Samantha Jones, plans to smuggle it out of Canada and deliver it to to her contact in New York Roth, Alan Arkin, when she lands at JFK Airport.For some reason Lisa gets cold feet when she sees Roth withing for her and hands the harmless looking doll over to the first person she runs into at the airport terminal photographer Sam Hendrix, Efrem Zimberlist Jr, for safe keeping. It's later when Roth & Lisa went to Hendridx's basement apartment in Greenwich village that he murdered Lisa in order not to split the take, the heroin, with her. The big mistake that Roth made was not realizing that in her not trusting him Lisa had earlier given the doll to the Hendrix's next door neighbor 15 year old Gloria, Julie Harrod! It wasn't until Roth murdered Lisa that he realized that the doll had disappeared from right under his nose! Now concocting a plan to get the doll back Roth gets in touch with two convicted con-men Mike Talman & former NYPD Sergeant Carlino, Richard Crenna & Jack Weston, to do all the leg work, in finding the missing doll, for him. What Roth Talman & Carlino never expected is who in the end was to do them all in! Sam Hendrix's blind and barely 100 pound dripping wet wife Susy, Audrey Hepburn! It's Susy who in the end would use the one thing she had over the trio to her advantage to put them out of commission: The Dark of Night!Great performances all around especially by Audry Hepburn as the blind confused and finally heroic Susy Hendrix. Being blind the three con-artists tried to trick Susy into handing over the doll to them in telling her that without it, as an alibi, her husband Sam would be implicate in Lisa's murder. With Lisa's body being placed by the trio a block away they came up with this cock & bull story about Sam having a secret love affair with her that went sour where Sam ended up murdering her! This sham of Roth Talman & Carlino worked for a while until Susy, with the help of her young friend Julie, got wise to them. The big roadblock in the con-artists plan was that Susy had no idea where the doll was! That's until late in the movie when Julie told her! And by then all bets were off, in Susy finding out the truth, in her giving up the doll to Roth Talman & Carlino. That's in Susy knowing that Roth who eventually murdered his two partners, Talman & Carlino, will never let her live to "see" the light of day after he got his hands on it! ***Spoilers*** Nail biting final with Susy fighting for her life as Roth starts to bear down on her, with a match and can of gasoline, in trying to find out where she had the doll hidden. Knowing that only the dark can save her the sightless Susy knocks out all the lights in her apartment to even the playing field with the by now, in being frustrated by her at every turn, deranged and psychotic Roth! The final few minutes of the film are really heart stopping with Roth, like Jason from the Friday the 13th movies, coming back to life to get a last chance to finally put Susy, with the kitchen knife that Susy stabbed him, away for good! It's a good thing that in this instance Susy was blind! If she could see the shock alone of a crazed madden and what seemed like dead Roth flying at her would have been enough to have her drop dead from fright!

Good acting by all in this creepy thriller of a movie. Aubrey is exceptionally good. Interesting story line. Sort of a Hitchcock thriller. Even though 90% of the movie takes place in the same set, it never gets in the way. One note.Since the Hepburn character is blind, why would the Alan Arkin character have to disguise himself so many times. And since this is New York, why no traffic or cars on the street. Also no neighbors or other people around. Just asking. No matter, it's really a good movie and should be on everyones "to see" list.Moree films of this ilk should be made today instead of the junk thats out now with nothing but special effects and Marvel movies. WAIT UNTIL DARK is a real movie.

Wait Until DarkSince sunlight doesn't matter to them, blind people should only work nightshifts.Fortunately, the blind woman in this thriller doesn't have a day job to worry about losing.When a drug mule stashes an antique doll filled with heroin on her husband (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.) during his flight home, sightless Susy (Audrey Hepburn) becomes the unwilling victim to the thugs (Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna, Jack Weston) who come to her apartment looking for it.In order to best the burglars, Susy exploits what remaining faculties she has by grabbing a kitchen knife and cutting all power to her place.With a top tier cast, a slow-burner script adapted from the Broadway production and a gripping score courtesy of Henry Mancini, Wait Until Dark is a testament to the resilience of both women and the disable. Lastly, if you can't steal from a blind woman maybe you shouldn't be a criminal.Green Lightvidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

Unbelievable suspense and magnificent acting is the hallmark of this all-time classic of the genre.  Alan Arkin gives a tour-de-force performance as a brutally sadistic psychopathic killer.  Audrey Hepburn is superb as Susie, the movie's heroine, who learns that she can take care of herself when she has to.  And, Richard Crenna demonstrates why he has been a staple of the entertainment industry for sixty years.  The man is as professional as he is handsome.

reviews.review_title: Suspenseful, on the edge of your seat thriller
reviews.content: If your one of those people who love Audrey Hepburn at her best, and you love mystery/thrillers this movie's for you. It just graps you right when you start watching it, makes you interested, you want to know what's going to happen next.Great plot, absolutely wonderful, who can do better than that. Blind woman doesn't know that the new friend she just met is drug smuggler. And when she goes into her room to get something in her closet, a DEAD WOMAN is in there and she doesn't know it.And Alan Arkin as the the main drug dealer, brillant, absolutely brillant. Just looking at him makes you scared. And just watching this is great. I really recommend this movie to anyone who likes thrillers, and A great all-star cast!

reviews.review_title: One of the best Suspense films ever
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies that i believe has ever been made. The suspense genre was born on this sort of film and should honestly go back.The movie centers around a recently blind woman Susy Hendrix(Audrey Hepburn) who is terrorized by thugs seeking a doll full of drugs.  With the help of her remaining senses and her young neighbor Gloria, she is about to save herself from the clutches of the tugs. Throughout the film the audience knows a great deal more than Susy Hendrix which creates a great tension in the plot.  Hepburn is wonderful as a blind woman and deserved the Oscar nomination for her portrayal.  The last few minutes of the movie are the best. I've been told that in these moments of the film in which all the lights are knocked off in Susy's apartment, theater owners would turn off the house lights to create total darkness and enhance the film. I recommend it to every person i meet.

Suzy (Audrey Hepburn) is a blind lady who is alone at home most of the day. Her husband, Sam (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.), accidentally brings home a doll stuffed with heroin. Three thugs plot to enter her home without her suspecting their motive. They hope to take advantage of her handicap but she is smarter than they expect.This movie has a lot of potential because it has a good central idea and is well cast. However, it is severely let down by what appears to be a hastily written screenplay. It is full of gaping, in-your-face plot holes. The three thugs walk in and out of Suzy's home like it is their own. She never locks the door. Even after an hour into the movie when she understands the dangerous nature of these men and when the tension is building up, that door is still unlocked. I am sorry, but it is difficult to get completely involved when your brain is screaming "Lock that damn door, lady!" There are other inconsistencies too. Gloria (Julie Herrod), Suzy's occasional companion, leaves Suzy's home without the thugs noticing her and uses a telephone but Suzy does not do the same when her own telephone is disconnected. At one point she douses the lead thug, Roat (Alan Arkin), in gasoline yet she drops the matchbox from her hand instead of threatening him with it.The script also suffers from poorly written supporting characters. Sam and his goal of making Suzy the champion blind lady are obnoxious. Mike (Richard Crenna), one of the subsidiary thugs, appears to appreciate Suzy better than her husband. Roat is caricature-ish and inspires no fear in us, the audience. That is not to say the movie has no positive points. Audrey Hepburn's Suzy is charming, smart and surprises us many a times with her resourcefulness. The increased acuteness of her other senses due to the lack of sight, is well portrayed. Ms. Hepburn is always a delight to watch and it works for the movie that she is on screen for about ninety percent of the run time. Gloria is a likable little brat and it would have been nice to see more of her. Ms Hepburn and Ms. Julie share a good chemistry between them.The building up tension towards the climax is done well. The trapped feeling of the lead character is well captured because almost the entire movie is shot inside a small apartment. The darkness in some of the scenes is also well utilized. However, it is somewhat marred by the above mentioned plot holes. This is a movie that could have been one of the best ever thrillers but falls short.

I first saw this late night on television in 2005 at first it wasn't my favourite film of Audrey's but now it's one of my favourite films of her's. Alan Arkin (who played drug dealer Harry Roat Jr) was hot in this film despite the fact his character terrorizes Audrey Hepburn, he should of had a Oscar nomination for his role. Audrey did a great job portraying a blind character. The theme music at the start of the film is one of my favourite movie theme tunes. I have to say I didn't get scared watching this film and thought Psycho was scarier. Richard Crenna and Jack Weston were great supporting characters. If they ever remake this film I think Johnny Depp should play Harry Roat Jr.

This is one of my favorite movies. The atmosphere is just marvelous inside the dark basement apartment that Audrey Hepburn lives in. Alan Arkin and his cohorts are very intense in their desire to have a heroin stuffed doll. What better prop to pick in the late sixties than a heroin stuffed doll - it was an ominous, campy prop to pick. Audrey Hepburn is thoroughly believable as a blind lady. The little girl in the movie with glasses is a perfect side character. Most of a standout is fabulous Alan Arkin playing several roles and showing incredible skill as an actor at a young age. I can't think of many movies I've enjoyed better. The mood is set from the very intro. The set design is first class. Richard Crenna brings a kind sensitivity to the movie which was unexpected.

reviews.review_title: Great film if only I could use that suspension of disbelief effectively enough
reviews.content: There is so much to say, but alas, sometimes less is more.Wait Until Dark (1967) Audrey, I love you Sadly, I could not believe the plot plausibility Such an elaborate con Call the neighbors, lock the door!

reviews.review_title: You'll have to suspend disbelief a bit, but creepy and worthwhile
reviews.content: It's hard to say whether Audrey Hepburn truly pulls off being blind in this movie, but this is a strong cast, and seriously creepy story. Alan Arkin is fantastic as the ruthless drug dealer who schemes with a couple of characters played by Richard Crenna and Jack Weston to trick Hepburn into letting them into her home, in search of a doll that was used to smuggle heroin and which ended up in her husband's possession. The film is not 100% convincing and you'll probably find yourself pointing out a few plot holes, but it's convincing enough, and I liked how taut the story-telling was. What could be more eerie than thinking you're alone in your apartment, but have three men with you in the room? We feel for this vulnerable blind woman and pull for her as she begins to figure out what's happening by paying attention to her other senses (and getting some help from a neighbor girl), and there is real tension as she does. You'll have to suspend disbelief a little bit to enjoy it, but it's certainly worth watching.

reviews.review_title: Audry Hepburn Proves You Can Fight Back Even With A Disability
reviews.content:
The first time I watched this movie was on TCM in 2017. It is about a young woman Lisa ( Samantha Jones) who gets involved in a smuggling ring. She is getting ready to board a plane with a doll full of heroin. When she boards the plane bound for New York, someone is watching her. He is on top of the roof making sure she has the goods, I believe the man is Roat ( Adam Arkin). When the plane arrives in New York, she gives the doll to Sam Hendrix ( Efren Zimbalist, Jr.) Sam is a photographer who is married to Suzi Hendrix ( Audry Hepburn). I believe Sam knows her, because later on he is suppose to take pictures of Lisa. She never shows for her photography session.When two men come looking for Lisa in a New York neighborhood, the apartment Lisa sends them two is not hers it's Suzi and Sam's. They look around for a while, then there is a knock at the door. It is Roat who has a plan for Mike ( Richard Crenna), and Carlino ( Jack Weston). The two know each other because they were just release from prison. Roat tells him about the job, but the price goes up. Mike and Carlino do not trust Roat, but decide to come in on the job. Mike wants to see whats in the closet, but at first Roat declines. After a small altercation, Roat gives him the key. When Mike looks around he discovers Lisa in a clothes bag. They realize they have to get rid of her, so they can look for that doll. When Lisa gave it to Sam, they know the doll is in the apartment somewhere.
