When Suzi returns they hid, but at first they have no idea she is blind, until she calls Sam. When she calls Sam they relax some, but are still guarded. Suzi knows someone is in the apartment, but thinks it's Gloria ( Julia Herrod). Gloria is a teenager who lives upstairs, and helps Suzi. She also has a thing for Suzi's husband. After she talks to Sam she leaves, Roat, Mike, and Carlino now get their plan together. When Suzi gets home Mike is at the door, he claims to be a friend of Sam's. Suzi thinks he is innocent as mike plays the part well, in fact she befriends Mike. When Night falls, the terror begins. Roat and Sgt. Carlino come in, I don't know why they call him Sgt. though? They try to get her to tell them where that doll could be, but she doesn't know? Roat who plays Roat Sr., and Roat Jr. comes into play, he comes into the place looking for something and takes Suzi's wedding photo. 
The Three of them continue to harass her from a phone booth across the street. Suzi is starting to get suspicious, especially when Roat Jr. comes in. She asks Gloria for help. She tells Gloria about the police car outside, but Gloria tells her there isn't one. She knows the two men aren't who the say they are, but still thinks Mike is a friend. She turns to Gloria and tells her she needs her help. If she she's any of the men she saw today, to call her, but just let it ring twice.
Suzi finds out the men are not who they say they are, but still thinks Mike is her friend. So she calls him and tells him she's got the doll. As soon as Suzi hangs up, her phone rings twice. She realizes Mike is in on it too, and has to hide the doll. Then things go from bad to worse, Roat shows up again kills Mike and goes after Suzi. Suzi fights back, by knocking out the light bulbs in the hall/apartment. She stabs him in the end, and is found behind the door of the refrigerator.
This is an exciting movie, it came out in the 60's and is somewhat dated. If you like thrillers, I would recommend seeing this gem. I 'm sure they have it on DVD, but maybe You can get lucky and discover it's playing on the TCM channel.

reviews.review_title: One of my favorite movies of all time - Top 5!
reviews.content: I saw this movie when I was 9 year old, at the matinée with my big brother. reviews.review_title: While dated, still a great example of what "suspense" should mean
reviews.content: I saw the play on Broadway with Lee Remick and Robert Duvall as a kid and it scared me to death. Then the movie did the same to me and the nation. I remember clearly all the talk of the last ten minutes of the film, which were the most intensely frightening filmed to that time.The script is dated in some ways: villains never swear and instead say things like "buzz off, kid!" The premise of a complicated scheme to locate a doll stuffed with heroin doesn't fly today when heroin is sent by the boat load.Still, Wait Until Dark shows what's missing in suspense movies of today: a tightly knit structure in which the payoff is delayed. Instead of periodic screams followed by quiet (or humorous) scenes, the script slowly increases the dread experienced by the audience, so that when it's time to scream, the audience needs to scream to release the emotional pressure.Think back to the movies that really scared you: Alien? The Exorcist? Jaws? Note that they all hold off showing what scares you, releasing little bits of info or images that heighten the dread. Contrast this to "horror" movies of today, like the recent remake of "Dawn of the Dead," in which you're shown the zombies in the first 10 minutes before you have time to care about the characters.So don't let the dated nature of the material deter you: see Wait Until Dark and re-discover what constitutes true suspense.

Audrey Hepburn (Susy) tried to salvage her marriage by making WAIT UNTIL DARK with her husband Mel Ferrer as the producer. Also working for director Terence Young, a British paratrooper Hepburn had bandaged up as a teenager nursing volunteer during WWII in Holland, these combined reminders of past traumas were so strong she insisted on playing the blind Susy with no eye prosthetic devices. Perhaps she was correct in thinking her "thousand-yard stare" evoked by the twin devils of the script and her personal strife would suffice to imply blindness for the more naive movie-goers of her time. No doubt the censorship code which prevailed into the early 1960s in the U.S. convinced the naive film fans of yesteryear that they "could not handle the truth" when it came to violence, gore, and an accurate depiction of physical disabilities. However, in 1963 Patty Duke WON an Oscar for portraying Helen Keller in the 1962 movie THE MIRACLE WORKER by ACTUALLY LOOKING BLIND, something the Oscar voters who stranded Hepburn as an also-ran in 1968 for DARK may have thought the self-costumed Paris fashion-clad designer-clothed fashion icon did not try hard enough to achieve. Susy asks her husband early on in DARK, "Do I have to be the world champion blind lady?" Evidently, the notoriously insecure Hepburn thought she had to be the world champion EVERYTHING, resulting in her divorcing a husband who did not make her feel like the world champion wife a year after their DARK collaboration. She would lick her wounds for the next nine years, prior to entering Sherwood Forest as an aging Lady Marion to Sean Connery's Robin Hood in the 1976 flop, ROBIN AND MARIAN.

reviews.content:
Wait Until Dark (1967) :
Brief Review -Indeed, a Classic "One-Room-Thriller" that nobody made after Hitchcock's 'Rope' by playing Blind. Audrey Hepburn in her career best role will make you forget many great thrillers of 60s. I must confess that this film has remained way underrated and compared to Alfred Hitchcock thrillers in 60s such as 'The Birds', 'Marnie', 'Torn Curtain' and 'Topaz', this one is far far ahead. I haven't added Hitchcock's early 60s classic 'Psycho' as i believe it's a great Classic Thriller. Well, Wait Until Dark isn't any less then. I must say that Hepburn's two thrillers in 60s 'Charade' and this one 'Wait Untill Dark' are so Hitchcockian that Hitchcock himself couldn't make. When i saw his 'Rope' starring James Stewart, i was shocked that it had remained so less known than his popular works which were actually not at all close the cinematic aspects of that film. I even wonder how 'North By Northwest' can get so much acclaim and not Rope and Charade and even Wait Until Dark? So, Wait Until Dark is "Blind" thriller with an extra "Eye" to every single detail. You just can't get over it. I know this formula from Comedies and Revenge Thrillers made in Indian cinema but the way Wait Until Dark has used it is way beyond masterwork. Every single frame, every single moment and every single movement in the film becomes unmissably important after first 20 minutes. Once Hepburn enters into the picture, there is no escape for you as an audience. Those next 85 minutes take you on a ride and how. That atmosphere, inteligent conversations, planning, detailed analysis everything about this film is worth watching. They don't make thrillers which are so real now days, i mean the probability of happening such things in real life is highest for any thriller. So, my final words are, DO NOT MISS IT AT ANY COST! You just can't afford the lost as a movie fan.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest.

A con artist named Lisa, who lives in Montreal, waits for a man to sew bags of heroin into a doll.She takes the doll on a flight to New York and notices a man spying on her.She gives the doll to a stranger, a photographer named Sam Hendrix.Then a small-time con artist Mike Talman and his partner Carlino arrive for a Greenwich Village apartment, where the photographer lives with his wife Susy.They are joined by Lisa's husband Harry Roat, who has killed his wife and forces those two to retrieve the doll.Then Susy is alone in the house and those criminals pose as an old friend, a police detective and a father-son pair.This way they want to get their hands on the doll.But it's not that easy, since Susy sees more than they know.And she is helped by Gloria, a girl who lives upstairs.Wait Until Dark (1967) is directed by Terence Young.The movie is originally a 1966 play by Frederick Knott, and it also shows in the film.It takes place mostly in one place.This is a marvelous movie, and so must the play be.Audrey Hepburn is brilliant as Susy Hendrix.She makes a really convincing blind woman.Alan Arkin is terrific and very scary as the main villain Roat, also Jr and Sr.Richard Crenna is great as Mike Talman.And so is Jack Weston as Carlino.Efrem Zimbalist Jr. is magnicifent as Sam Hendrix.Great job by the young actress Julie Herrod, who plays Gloria.Samantha Jones does the role of Lisa.Mel Ferrer is heard as French Canadian radio speaker.This is an intenseful thriller.It is most intense when Susy, the blind woman breaks all the light bulbs and the mad man is in the house.She manages to throw the chemical in Mr. Roat's face and pouring gasoline on him.Roat, not knowing what a strong woman he is facing, gets stabbed by her.A movie really worth seeing.

I saw this movie when it first came out (I was 9). It scared the crap out of me and everyone else who saw it. But it deserves it's place in film history as one of those novel films that elevated the genre.

reviews.review_title: It should have been Shelley Winters
reviews.content: I realize Wait Until Dark is a classic, but after you've seen it three or four times, it tends to lose its magic. You realize the dialogue feels very play-ish and stilted because, after all, it was almost literally transcribed from the Broadway production. You get over the shock and see it's hardly more than a regular cheap thriller from the 1960s. And you start to criticize Audrey Hepburn's over-the-top performance until you realize that the melodrama is only partially her fault: she shouldn't have been cast in the first place.Audrey Hepburn is the epitome of grace, class, and composure (which is why she was a terrible choice for Eliza Doolittle). As a recently blind woman, she's supposed to still be finding her way while feeling a little helpless and lost. You're supposed to feel sorry for her and afraid that something bad will happen to her. Instead, Audrey looks as though she just stepped out of the beauty parlor and doesn't have a care in the world. Her hair is coiffed, her clothes are clean, pressed, and matching, and her composure calm. Just imagine if the lead were played by Shelley Winters. Shelley would have had messy hair, clothes in disarray, and a constant snivel and warble in her voice. She would have made the character vulnerable and nearly pathetic, so the danger would have seemed real. Nothing could ever happen to Audrey Hepburn!However, villains Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna, and Jack Weston certainly try their hardest, and there are several scenes that are eerie, intense, and frightening. The first time you see this movie, you'll shriek and scream and have a marvelous time. I've just seen it too many times. And as my famous phrase lingers on, it really should have been Shelley Winters. Efrem Zimbalist Jr has a horrible character as Audrey's husband. He's nearly cruel, and downright unsupportive of his recently blind wife. He thinks tough love will be helpful to her, but the way his lines are written and delivered seem as though he can't stand her and find her new handicap irritating and bothersome to his daily routine. Thankfully, he's hardly in the movie so it doesn't ruin anything. Alan's tour-de-force is a role that countless actors covet when the play is produced on the stage. He's creepy, cold, and nearly unrecognizable. If you've never seen this classic, try it out close to Halloween. It's very fun.

reviews.review_title: This is the best suspense movie of all time...
reviews.content: I love this movie - I've seen it many, many times. Audrey Hepburn is terrific and so is Alan Arkin. So many suspense movies rely on a person's fear of monsters or demons (or such) and use disgusting scenes of 'blood and guts' to horrify the viewer, rather than developing a powerful story with real suspense to involve the viewer. In contrast, this movie is incredibly suspenseful while focusing on real human motivations and misdeeds. She's such a spunky, warm, and believable character - you'll get caught up in her plight and in the cunning manipulations used by the bad guys. And the story is clever and innovative: Hepburn finds herself trapped with very little chance of getting help from the outside world, and she must rely on her resourcefulness and quick wits to survive. Many movies have since used this type of setup to create suspense, but this is the best of all.

Audrey Hepburn clearly didn't fit the classic Hitchcock profile of a mysterious blonde but that didn't stop her appearing in two of the 60's better Hitchcockian thrillers, "Charade" and this, Bond director Terence Young's "Wait Until Dark". Nowadays I'm sure there'd be all sorts of woke outcry about a sighted person playing the part of a blind woman, but this was back then and the bigger question is whether Hepburn can convince the audience that she has indeed lost her vision, especially as the production doesn't have her wearing shades or otherwise make up her eyes in such a way as to convey her situation.I think she plays her disability well throughout. We're told that she only lost her sight a year ago which explains her relative familiarity with the surroundings of her New York apartment, a definite asset if a knife-toting psychopath who's already murdered three people comes a-knocking.Said psychopath is Alan Arkin who really gets to ham and almost camp it up as Mr Roat, who will kill and kill again in order to lay his hands on a child's doll containing a load of smuggled heroin. This doll came into Hepburn's apartment via her husband, the wonderfully-named Efram Zimbalist Jr, to whom it was passed by its frightened mule, Samantha Lee, who bumped into him on an aeroplane flight.Now, with hubby sent chasing across town by Arkin on fool's errands, his wife is at the seeming mercy of the ruthless villain and his two recruited henchmen. In the end, our heroine will have to show courage, adaptability and ingenuity if she's to survive the night in this adult "Home Alone" situation.The crux of the film is the extended sequence at the end when it's just Arkin and Hepburn facing-off in her darkened apartment and director Young certainly heightens the tension as Hepburn strives to even up the odds, the better to boost her survival prospects, by breaking all the lights in the room.There's an interestingly discordant soundtrack by Henry Mancini to further identify the viewer with Hepburn's plight and I liked Young's bold idea to black out the screen for more than a few seconds at a key point. Otherwise it's a relatively conventional if still enjoyably entertaining twist on the old damsel on distress theme, lit up by the closing encounter between Hepburn and Arkin.

reviews.review_title: Hepburn Tries Something Different in This Promising, but Limited, Stage Adaptation
reviews.content: Audrey Hepburn and Alan Arkin tangle in this one-room thriller, pitting Arkin's slimy underworld fixer (and his two slightly-less-unseemly cohorts) against Hepburn's lone feeble, blind housewife in a test of wills. Arkin's gang doesn't want to make a scene if they don't have to - they're just after the dope-stuffed doll that fell into her possession - but patience wears thin as their con act falters and she continues dodging questions.It's a promising setup, if a little dull in practice, but neither of the against-type primary roles really click. Hepburn is sweet but stiff in her central role, out-of-place in an unfamiliar genre, while Arkin's twisted erudite hipster is more of a hand-wringing silver age comic book villain than the dark, gritty, street-level threat he's obviously meant to be. A crafty final showdown between the pair levels the playing field, smartly ratcheting tension in a string of almost pitch-black struggles over a knife, a fridge door and a can of gasoline. That scene was the subject of much promotion during the film's original run, aided by a gimmick that had theater-owners extinguish all lighting (even the exit signs?) to enhance the effect. The white-knuckled climax works well enough, and I'm sure the atmospheric bonus would've been a neat wrinkle, but it's insufficient compensation for the half-cooked hour of water-treading that precedes it.

Being from a younger generation, I'm surrounded by new-age horror and thriller films that focus more on crafty kills and jumpscares than the actual plot. And that's fine since our attention spans are shorter and we've become more impatient, but it's nice to have a film that takes its time leading you up and freaking you out until you get to those final twenty minutes. I first saw this film in high school, recommended by my graphics teacher who was older than dirt, in our Reels movie club. He was so excited about the film and even did all the effort of darkening the room so that we'll have "the full effect." I must say, the movie freaked me out so much and the little jumpscares dotted in the movie scared me more each time until the final one had me and my classmates screaming and gripping our seats. After the movie, we all talked about it and some of my classmates wondered how such an old movie could scare us more than the newer movies being released today. And it's all in the plot and build up. Many movies today lack a certain amount of build up or a decent plot to hook onto. Wait Until Dark will have you watching the entire time. The thing about the movie is, you go in thinking it's some simple plot about a blind woman who's going to get robbed, but it's more than that. The criminals aren't your average "Sticky Bandits" types who go in guns blazing, no, they're the type that love to toy and mess with their victims. Well, it's mostly just Roat (Alan Arkin) who's calling the shots, but his sidekicks are also part of the trickery (but they get their "fair share" towards the end). The movie is complex, very complex. It requires the viewer to pay attention to props being used, to the sounds heard, to the words spoken by the characters. It's not something you can just watch and follow along. If you don't pay attention, something will happen later that will have you giving the infamous "huh" look. Then towards the end you get to see brilliant lighting techniques, camera angles, and how the director literally blinds you so you're eyes are wondering around trying to catch a glimpse of what's going on, what's happening, what fell!! It's amazing.I recently watched this movie again (in the dark, alone in my house) , since I'm more older and mature, and I still screamed and jumped. Even when I knew what was going to happen! That's how you know this movie is timeless. Plus, it deserves a second watch so you can catch anything you missed, such as how I missed key plot points about the doll, but caught them the second time around. I recommend this to anybody, young and old, and I'm going to have my friends watch it in the dark like I did so they can experience it too. Very fun and very thrilling.

I was satisfied with the lack of gore and foul language that is so eminent in today's thrillers. Wait Until Dark is a slick thriller that keeps you interested and the suspense never lags. Audrey Hepburn plays (Suzy Hendrix) a recently blinded woman beautifully realized by Hepburn's skills. Her husband Sam (Zimbalist) is her newlywed husband who has inadvertently received a toy doll at the airport from some random woman. Unbeknownst to him it is filled with narcotics. Alan Arkin (Roat) is the main schemer and he wants that doll. Roat employs the help of Richard Crenna (Mike Talman) and Jack Weston (Carlino) to confiscate this valuable doll from Suzy once they realize it is in her possession. Roat devises a sleazy plot to fool our blind and lovely heroine into believing they are there to help her. But their scheme only lasts so long until Suzy, with the aide of her neighbor friend (Herrod), put two and two together and realize the duplicity in the three con men's plan. What we have is a pretty engaging thriller that makes you worry about our vulnerable and sweet Suzy. She may be delicate and soft, but she proves to be no cream puff when she comes to the final showdown. The performances are good. Arkin plays his Roat cunning and slick with a slight creepiness. Crenna gives a solid and gimlet eyed performance. Weston is good as the fumbling flunky of the three. But it is Audrey Hepburn who captures our hearts and makes us feel the real sense of isolation and fear with her vulnerable and wonderful performance. The final scene is very sweet and touching. This may not be everyone's idea of a top-notch thriller, but if you watch this movie and don't fall in love with Hepburn, something is wrong.

reviews.review_title: Don't Watch It For The Story
reviews.content: Most of the plot details of "Wait Until Dark" are so very unbelievable that it fails as a suspense movie; my buddies and I actually laughed through most of it. Nonetheless, thoughtful movie enthusiasts will enjoy "Wait Until Dark" as a classic example of late-1960's suspense films for the quality of it's production values. While not a "cineast," I still recognize and appreciate the style of direction, lighting and editing of this movie for being typical of it's time; many others will too. It's worthwhile watching for this very reason. Compare it to 1968's "Rosemary's Baby;" One movie is truly suspenseful and gripping to the end, one is, well, not. Both have a similar style though, a style common to many late-1960's dramatic films.An additional, though perhaps frivolous, reason to watch "Wait Until Dark" is seeing both Alan Arkin and Richard Crenna in earlier movie roles. If you enjoy watching an actor's development over the years, you'll enjoy seeing Arkin and Crenna as younger actors in somewhat minor supporting roles. Audrey Hepburn, on the other hand, is a waste in this movie; had it been made thirty years later, it would have starred Markie Post and been shown on Lifetime.On the whole, "Wait Until Dark" is worthwhile solely as a period piece; it's amusing (an maybe interesting) to watch at two in the morning, but not worth renting.

(And his costume changes are rather silly.) Not one of the bad guys is believable and within fifteen minutes you know the ending and the rest is just people messing around. reviews.review_title: A myriad of plot holes and implausible details, nonetheless one of the greatest film thrillers ever.
reviews.content: I'll mention my objections, then why I love this movie anyway.1) New York City, specifically Greenwich Village, Lower Manhattan: A van is able to park on a near-deserted street in the middle of the Village- it is used by the three villains in the movie. Nearby, they also have a sedan parked in an equally untrafficked parking lot. In New York City, in one of the most crowded areas of Manhattan. A girl approaches a man, offering Girl Scout cookies, and the sidewalk is otherwise deserted. Does this Friday night Greenwich Village exist in some alternate universe?A 12-year-old girl, whose parents have split up and is living with her neglectful mother, is ostensibly precocious and streetwise, as one would expect such a New York City latchkey girl to be. Yet apparently she is unfamiliar with vans (never mind vans' ubiquity as delivery and cab vehicles in the city) and refers to one she sees a "a kind of squatty truck." Really?2) Stupid behavior by ostensibly smart adults. A blind woman and her husband live in an apartment in the Village- not just an apartment, but a basement (also called a "garden" apartment by savvy real estate agents) apartment, the kind most susceptible to break-ins. Yet they nonchalantly go about their business without locking the door to the apartment. Are we in New York City or Mayberry?A professional photographer, returning to New York from Canada, agrees to accept a doll from a woman, a perfect stranger, on the basis of a made-up story as both clear customs at JFK International Airport. Savvy, experienced New York City dwellers accept packages for safekeeping from strangers all the time, right?A pair of ostensibly streetwise veteran con artists wander into previously mentioned unlocked apartment, casually putting their fingerprints everywhere, on the basis of a typed note from previously mentioned doll-woman, who is their former partner in crime and whom they've been led to believe is the rightful tenant of said apartment, taking a full 10 minutes to realize that she has no typing/secretarial skills and that they've laid themselves open to being set up.3) The blind woman goes back to apartment while the three hoodlums are there, yet doesn't detect their presence.4) Timeline. Said blind woman was blinded in accident just over a year before the action in the film, yet in that time has met and married previously mentioned photographer, and they've established a pal-around routine as if they'd been together for years and she'd been blind for far longer.5) Efrem Zimbalist, Jr. To put it mildly, his presence in the film (mercifully brief; confined to a few scenes) is not an asset. He plays a thinly-altered variation of the steely-jawed, high-school-football-coach-spouting-rousing-clichés, all-American hero he played concurrently on the popular TV series "The FBI," a right-wing weekly propaganda outlet for J. Edgar Hoover and his PR department. The scenes between him and Hepburn as his wife are cringe-worthy "you can do it!" kitsch, a stereotype of the crusty-but-heart-of-gold man acting as savior to the ill and/or disabled (but typically still fully photogenic) woman. As always, Zimbalist's emotional and acting range are between A and A. Ugh. This guy's supposed to be a highly-sought-after art and professional photographer in Bohemian Greenwich Village? Ronald Reagan would have been just as convincing.6) Several murders take place on or offscreen in this neighborhood, yet do not bring the police nearby or arouse any interest of the (apparently invisible or non-existent) neighbors. But then, as I said before, this is one strangely underpopulated, nearly deserted New York City.OK, now I've gotten all that off my chest, I can discuss why I love this movie anyway. First of all, it is, outside of Hitchcock ("Rope," "Dial M for Murder," "Rear Window," the last of which shared with "Wait Until Dark" the same playwright, Frederick Knott), the best claustrophobic, within-one-small-apartment thriller in cinematic history (I'm referring to films where all or almost all of the action takes place within a tiny confined space). The pacing (aside from aforementioned, exposition-setting cringeworthy Zimbalist/Hepburn scenes) and the slow building of suspense to an unpredictable climax are simply superb.And the acting is, Zimbalist aside, outstanding. Richard Crenna as a veteran con artist does well stepping out of the nice-guy persona he had created on the TV sitcom "The Real McCoys," and Jack Weston as his oafish partner in crime Carlino is appropriately thuggish but still likable. Julie Herrod, repeating her Broadway performance, does a nice job as bratty-but-sympathetic Gloria, the tween-age girl helping the blind woman. Samantha Jones is skilled in her brief role as a glamorous and beautiful drug mule smuggling heroin across the Canada-U.S. border.Audrey Hepburn was not really exploring new acting territory (for her) as the frail and vulnerable innocent in danger (she played very similar roles in "Charade," "The Children's Hour," and, to a certain extent, in her lead debut, "Roman Holiday"), but her performance as blind woman Susy Hendrix at the mercy of three desperados is still a standout.But the biggest kudos has to go to Alan Arkin as chief bad guy Harry Roat, a.k.a. Harry Roat Sr., a.k.a. Harry Roat Jr., a cool, stiletto-toting hipster in shades and a black leather jacket who will scare the bejesus out of you. It is tribute to Arkin's range as a comedic and serious actor when you consider the three roles he played in two years' time: as the sympathetic but humorous executive officer of a Soviet submarine in the Cold War-confrontation comedy "The Russians Are Coming, The Russians Are Coming!" (1966), as the scary but entertaining sociopath Roat in "Wait Until Dark" (1967), and as the sweet, tragic, deaf watchmaker John Singer in "The Heart Is A Lonely Hunter" (1968).

reviews.review_title: classic movie with a great idea
reviews.content: This movie is extremely well done and just an overall enjoyable experience. Some may complain it is a little slow at the beginning of the movie, or for most of it, but it is supposed to be like that. I loved the casting as Audrey Hepburn and it actually added to the character. There are very few times when I like identifying the character with the actor, but in this case because everyone loves Hepburn so much, the love passes to the character quite easily. She of course does a phenomenal job and I loved seeing the character grow through out the movie. Alan Arkin was brilliant and I loved seeing this side of him. I have not seen many of his movies, but this one is such a stark contrast from what I am used to it kind of floored me. Of course the last 15 minutes of the movie left me literally on the edge of my seat, and out of breathe. I was not sure how it was going to end and not even sure if she would survive. I thought the movie kept enough twists and turns in the plot and kept one rooting for Hepburn through out whole movie it was never slow for me. What surprised me was learning that this was first a play. I can usually pick that up, but the movie kept me in the moment so well I was not able to pick it up. Looking back it is obvious, but not during the viewing. I do wish that they showed the warning at the beginning of the film instead of leaving it in the special features. Hopefully on later releases they will put the warning in because that is the whole point of the movie. Luckily I had an idea of what has going to happen so it was fine, but those who do not know what they are getting into when watching the movie it would make a big impact seeing that warning. I would recommend this movie to movie fans, but not everyone. A very well executed movie with a great cast.

reviews.review_title: The 'mother of all thrillers'; cinema history's scariest scene.
reviews.content: 'Wait Until Dark' is the scariest movie in the history of cinema. It puts to shame the slash and gore garbage which is imposed on us by modern day Hollywood. Audrey Hepburn, maybe the most beautiful and classiest actress to ever appear on screen, plays a blind woman to perfection. Her husband, played by Efrem Zimbalist Jr., inadvertently brings home a cocaine-filled toy doll from an overseas trip. Three drug dealers create a clever scam as Efrem's 'buddies' to worm their way into Audrie's below-ground-level apartment to get the doll. Every second of this classic reeks of suspense and fear. Alan Arkin is absolutely ferocious in his drug-dealer intensity portrayal of an evil man who will stop at nothing, including killing his companions, to get the doll. Arkin is perfect in this role; he 'inhabits' it from head to toe; he is more 'real' in this role than real drug dealers in the real world. If you bumped into Arkin's character on the street in the real world, just his physical look, his world-weary face, his droll yet threatening speaking would have you shaking in your boots; evil has never seen a scarier portrayal in American cinema. During the last 1/4 hour or so of the movie is the single scariest scene to ever come out of moviedom. If it doesn't make you jump out of your seat, you must be clinically dead. This thriller is an absolute 'must see' before you die. Hang on!

reviews.review_title: This movie is a REAL thriller

Arkin does a really chilling psychopathic killer, and Hepburn is vulnerable -- but not too vulnerable.  Probably the most memorable scene for me is nearing the climax when Hepburn's apartment is completely dark -- except for one small light. The woman sitting directly behind me stood up and screamed as if it was she who was being attacked by Arkin.  Very convincing.

reviews.review_title: A Twisted Journey into a blind woman's worst nightmare.....

Audrey Hepburn plays Suzy Hendrix, Sam's wife, a woman recently blinded after a car crash, who three criminals cleverly try and deceive to retrieve the heroin filled doll that they believe is in her possession. After murdering Lisa for trying to get the doll away from them, the trio starts in on some very sick reindeer games with Suzy........With one of the most heart-stopping climaxes since "Psycho" and "Fatal Attraction", "Wait Until Dark" will keep you gasping until the very last second, when everything gets a little dark..........

With that being said, this movie is a viseral twisting thriller that will not disappoint and will stay with you for a time. I definitely recommend watching it, in the dark, with someone you can grab onto during the suspenseful parts because once this one gets going it's a hair-raising ride to the last scene.

When a woman working as a drug mule tries to double cross her associates...she winds up dead.But they can't find the doll containing the heroin, because she passed it off to a random man in the airport.The cronies manage to track this man down, but still can't find the doll.So they form a fraudulent narrative about framing the man for the murder of the woman, in order to try and trick his blind wife into giving up it's location.But she doesn't know where it is...so she can't help them.However, she is clever enough to realize that they're up to something.And, with the help of her young friend Gloria...plays them at their own game.Hiding the doll, because she knows it's the only thing that's keeping them from killing her.So she uses the darkness to give herself the advantage.But it might not be quite enough to save her...so she'll have to take it into her own hands so as to save herself.And she's certainly a survivor.When it's all over, the film acts as a parable.With the moral of this story being...don't mess with a superheroine.7 out of 10.

Gasoline is dumped all over a small enclosed room, then matches and torches of paper are lit amidst all the fumes and nothing happens?  A doll stuffed with a small amount of heroin is desperately and painstakingly sought by people who never take the time to simply look for it, even though it is in the same room they are in the entire time?  Laughable in many ways.  High ratings are hard to understand for this awkwardly fumbling clunker.

A film that will have you at the edge of your seat in this psychological thriller called Wait Until Dark. It's a story of a young blind woman (Audrey Hepburn) being manipulated by three criminals. Henry Mancini's musical score is quite nail-biting and intense as the score that he composed fits the film's tone and atmosphere. The acting from Audrey Hepburn and Alan Arkin are phenomenal performances as the two battle their wits during the film's climax. Wait Until Dark is such an intense thriller that makes you want to scream when the film gets quite intriguing.

It's a peculiarly interesting paradox, how a plot revolving around a situation so unpleasant results in a film so enjoyable. Very well acted out, the movie brings out the bitterness of a thriller without exaggerating its criminal elements. Not one second throughout the running time did I feel uninterested, let alone bored, and it is indeed very rare to find this in any movie, even the greatest of them. The plot is very creatively woven, the pacing is perfect, and the direction is great, especially taking into consideration that most of the movie is set in one place and that it involved shooting in the "dark." Audrey Hepburn of course gives a great performance as always and so do the rest of the cast, but she specifically plays a blind woman so meticulously it is weirdly alluring. Wait Until Dark is ultimately what cinema was made to be: compelling.

Chilling atmosphere with eerie music, and haunting direction.

Irish director Terence Young's horror crime thriller Wait Until Dark (1967) is still unnerving. Young lets his suspense thriller breathe with characters constantly reacting to every little sound and movement during this tense home invasion film. It's a very unique and specific story about a blind woman getting gaslit by two robbers and a murderer as they want to search her home for a little doll. Young makes Wait Until Dark get scarier and scarier until you feel like Audrey Hepburn is trapped.

Writers Frederick Knott, Robert Carrington, and Jane-Howard Hammerstein create an enthralling horror narrative that makes you feel so nervous and sorry for Audrey Hepburn's lone woman trying to figure out this brewing mystery as she's being lied to by everyone around her. I'm impressed that Wait Until Dark is so meticulously detail oriented about every clue and hint about what happened to this doll and where it could be as these robbers frantically search and manipulate their way into this home.

It's neat seeing all the Montreal and New York sights in the backdrop and 1960's fashion everywhere. Producer Mel Ferrer really got Young neat locations. He cameos as the voice of the Canadian radio speaker too! George Jenkins' art direction makes a quaint New York apartment look sinister and a menacing place to be. George James Hopkins & Ward Preston's set decoration provides all these cute knick-knacks for Hepburn's home that looks like you could live there.

Young's direction is fascinating with his chilling atmosphere and intimate feel like you're right there. Wait Until Dark is similar to Alfred Hitchcock's Rope all in one location and features killers maneuvering around Gene Milford's artful cuts that keep you in suspense with these seamless cuts that flow from room to room. 108 minutes pass by in moments. Charles Lang's cinematography goes from sweeping panning shots outdoors to these sharp shots indoors that hold your attention on the necessary details. The unique way Wait Until Dark is shot lets your eyes linger on every detail of this home as the mystery unfolds. 

Audrey Hepburn is delightful and sympathetic as Susy Hendrix. Her acting as if she's blind is really entertaining and moving. You feel her frustrations and fears, while admiring her acute sense of hearing, space, and movements. I found Hepburn very charming and engaging as you're always aware of when she's picking up on when she is being lied to by these three criminals. Audrey Hepburn was so pretty and captivating in every second of Wait Until Dark.

Alan Arkin is captivating as the mysterious Roat with his unnerving manner of speech and knife Geraldine. He plays multiple roles with a real sinister malice to his villain Roat. Richard Crenna is intriguing as the enigmatic Mike Talman. He plays the two-faced crook who is directly gaslighting Hepburn with such ease and confidence. Crenna looks like an evil Roger Moore. Efrem Zimbalist Jr. is good as Hepburn's often absent husband Sam, who can be both dispassionate and caring. Jack Weston is fun as the suspicious and self-serving Detective Carlino. He's very forceful and eager as he lies and intimidates his way for information.

Samantha Jones is lovely as Lisa. She's the spitting image of Sharon Tate. She pulls off her doll handoff very well. Julie Herrod is excellent as the young girl Gloria. Her tantrums and casual observations are a nice juxtaposition to Hepburn's graceful composure. Jean Del Val cameos as the old man who makes the doll for Jones' Lisa.

Composer Henry Mancini's creepy score is simply haunting. His dissonant chord stab and eerie piano melodies plucking away. He goes from diabolical sounding classical pieces to softer jazz passages at times. I love the music throughout Wait Until Dark. Sound designer Everett A. Hughes' very particular use of sound really emphasizes just exactly what Hepburn's blind lady can hear. Every mistake the crooks make is noted by her through her hearing. Gordon Bau really gave Hepburn a natural glow with his make-up too.

In short, I thoroughly enjoyed Wait Until Dark. It is an underrated suspense thriller that's often forgotten, but well worth seeking out. If you've ever liked Hitchcock's pictures, then Terence Young's Wait Until Dark has something special in store for you.

More than fifty years after its release, Wait Until Dark still packs a punch. Susy (Audrey Hepburn), a blind woman, finds that she is in possession of a doll that is sought after by three dangerous and desperate criminals who devise a devious plan to retrieve their property, which happens to be filled with heroin.  While the first half of the film is a bit convoluted and implausible, the second half more than compensates, with a finale that won't be forgotten and possibly the king of all jump scares.  Hepburn is great in the lead role, but the show is stolen by Alan Arkin's performance as Harry Roat, a ruthless, psychotic killer who leads the attempt to retrieve the missing contraband.

Audrey Hepburn and Alan Arkin tangle in this one-room thriller, pitting Arkin's slimy underworld fixer (and his two slightly-less-unseemly cohorts) against Hepburn's lone feeble, blind housewife in a test of wills. Arkin's gang doesn't want to make a scene if they don't have to - they're just after the dope-stuffed doll that fell into her possession - but patience wears thin as their con act falters and she continues dodging questions.

It's a promising setup, if a little dull in practice, but neither of the against-type primary roles really click. Hepburn is sweet but stiff in her central role, out-of-place in an unfamiliar genre, while Arkin's twisted erudite hipster is more of a hand-wringing silver age comic book villain than the dark, gritty, street-level threat he's obviously meant to be. A crafty final showdown between the pair levels the playing field, smartly ratcheting tension in a string of almost pitch-black struggles over a knife, a fridge door and a can of gasoline. That scene was the subject of much promotion during the film's original run, aided by a gimmick that had theater-owners extinguish all lighting (even the exit signs?) to enhance the effect. The white-knuckled climax works well enough, and I'm sure the atmospheric bonus would've been a neat wrinkle, but it's insufficient compensation for the half-cooked hour of water-treading that precedes it.

This isn't really a horror movie, but rather a thriller. They really don't make movies like this anymore and it's nice to see something "terrifying" that lacks blood and gore. Audrey did an amazing job and is quite convincing as a blind character. Definitely worth watching. 1967 film Wait Until Dark, adapted from Frederick Knott's 1966 play - and that is a considerable amount, given that it's one of the greatest movie thrillers of its generation - my first question is this: what on earth goes through Audrey Hepburn's mind when she's asked to appear in this movie? You have here a woman whose screen persona is completely built around her classy Continental elegance, whose personal life was marked by serious-minded humanitarianism, and you drop her into a horror-thriller about a heroin dealer antagonising a blind woman - it all seems so incomprehensible that Hepburn's seventeenth starring role should be such a grubby, grotty turn from all of the princesses and doe-eyed gamines and society women . As a teenager, I used to take the subway into Manhattan Saturday mornings and go to the movies. One of the most memorable of these films was without a doubt 'Wait Until Dark'. This taut thriller still stands far above other more recent entries into this genre. The reason for this persistence in excellence is this film does not depend on the typical slasher flicks special effects. These blood and gore scenes are good for a moment but soon become old. Wait Until Dark depends more on the human mind, a technique that can thrill far more than any fake blood and dismembered body parts. Susy (Audrey Hepburn) is a young woman who lives in New York City, is married to a successful photographer (Efrem Zimbalist Jr), and she is blind. While her husband is on a business trip, a beautiful blond slips a doll into his belongings, one that conceals a large quantity of heroin. The blond winds up dead (in Suzy's apartment), and the doll is also somewhere in the apartment. The main crook Roat (Alan Arkin) is determined to get the drugs back and deceptively enlists the aid of two other criminals, Mike (Richard Crenna) and Carlino (Jack Weston). The three men will pose as police officers to deceive the poor blind girl into letting them into the apartment where they can search for the drug right under her nose.

What ensues is a brilliantly orchestrated cat and mouse game largely between Roan and Suzy which itself sets this film above the typical Hollywood thriller. Rather than sitting back and surrendering to gory effects the audience is expected to think, to truly care about Suzy and root for her survival. Suzy is not the usual hapless damsel in distress; she is bright, resourceful and perceptive, more than a match for the clever Roat. Being blind turns out not to be a disadvantage to Suzy. It gives her the ability to notice little things the sighted would have overlooked. Things like furniture slightly moved the constant playing with the window blinds (a signal between the crooks) and the movements of the men throughout her apartment. It dawns on Suzy that something is amiss and she begins to prepare for the worse. While not a criminal mastermind Roat devises a plan that seemingly is brilliant. He underestimates how easy it will be to fool the blind woman but the manner in which he manipulates the other two men is inspired. The ending is shrouded in darkness. When I saw this film in my youth, the gimmick was for the theater to dim the house lights to the edge of the legal limit to accentuate the tension. It did, and I remember it now several decades later. You might want to try this at home.

One of the factors that help to propel this film to the heights it has achieved is the cast. Audrey Hepburn takes a character that normally would be considered helpless and turns her around into a sharp and incredibly bright young woman. Her performance lulls the audience into accepting her as determined but physically helpless only to watch her inner strength and determination forced to the surface. There is a spectacular beauty to how Hepburn places the character development of Suzy carefully, gradually allowing the audience's empathy to grow. Little hints to the self-reliance given from the start but as the film progresses we see just how strong she is. Arkin gives the performance of his lifetime here. He plays three characters in his plot against Suzy, Roat, Roat Jr. and Roat Sr. the subtle difference in how he plays each role is an exhibition of how an actor should approach a character. What impressed me most here is the amount of control these two leads display. They take the time and effort required to allow the audience to get to know these people, what motivates them and what is behind their reactions. Crenna and Weston give solid performances as the ancillary characters here. Each of these two men is capable of strong performances, and they give them to us. As low-level crooks, they are baited by Roat, manipulated and controlled by him. Their desperation is visceral; the audience can feel the emotions these men hold just under the surface.

Director Terence Young knows how to please an audience. He is responsible for three of the early (and best) James Bind films, 'Doctor No,' 'From Russia with Love' and 'Thunderball.' You may wonder if a director used to such action-oriented films can handle a far more cerebral thriller, the answer is a resounding yes. His control of the all important pacing is gifted. While most thrillers seem to feel that an initial shock required at the start of the film, Young give the audience time to acclimate to the situations and characters. He develops the plot slowly, like a fine dinner left to simmer and merges the flavors. He exhibits the same control of the lighting. Due to the specifics of this film, this is even greater than usual. As the ending approaches the lights dim, one by one, darkening the theater reinforcing the events on screen. Shadows become something out of a nightmare as our concern for the plight of Suzy increases. Young manipulates the emotions of the audience to perfection.

This film is an astounding example how actors, each great in their right, can interact with such amazing perfection that the synergy derived by the cast is nothing short of brilliant. Mr. Zimbalist and Mr. Weston were so brilliant in their portrayal of the soldier villains Mike and Carlino that a substantial baseline established the foundation for the coming terror flawlessly.

Wait Until Dark is a film I had never heard of until quite recently. After enjoying some other thrillers starring Audrey Hepburn, especially Charade, I knew I had to watch this film. And while I was skeptical of the films direction upon first glance (as it was directed by the same guy that directed three James Bond movies; Dr. No, From Russia with Love, and Thunderball, great films, but was not picturing Terence Young to direct a suspense thriller), it turns out that Wait Until Dark is not only well-made and well-acted, but it's definitely one of the most entertaining suspense thrillers ever made.

Meet Susy Hendrix (Audrey Hepburn), a housewife that's still learning to cope with blindness that was the result of a recent accident. She has a loving but always away husband (Efrem Zimbalist Jr.) and has a strong friendship with young neighbor Gloria (Julie Herrod). Things get complicated when criminals, led by the sadistic Roat (Alan Arkin), break into her apartment, going after a missing baby doll that she may or may not have, a doll that the crooks used to smuggle heroin into the country. Alone and with her husband away, Susy has to use her resourcefulness and her knowledge of her small apartment to get out of this situation alive.

The film also stars Richard Crenna and Jack Weston as the other crooks and Samantha Jones in a small part as Lisa, the woman who first had the doll.

I wasn't sure what I was going to think of Wait Until Dark when the opening credits started rolling. The beginning was a little slow and a little complicated to follow and Audrey Hepburn doesn't even appear until 25 minutes into the picture. But it turns out, the more the film progresses, the more engaging the plot is and the more suspenseful the mystery is. My other fear on this film was that the crooks were going to be these one-dimensional characters who end up raiding the house, the end, good bye. But what makes Wait Until Dark innovative is how the crooks manage to do their plotting. They don't just raid the house, no (and this is a mouthful) they take the nicest talking crook, make him like Hepburn as a friend, gain her confidence in getting him the doll, making the leader pose as two real insane nuts, and using the rough sounding guy posing as the police in order for Hepburn to just give them the doll. And all I have to say about this is... brilliant. An engaging plot like this causes Wait Until Dark to be as psychologically complex and shocking as an Alfred Hitchcock movie. 

Even more unique about the film is its cinematography. Rather than the average thriller where we're treated to rich, exotic locations and over-the-top action, 98% of the film is set in the apartment, giving the film more of a claustrophobic look, and it works fantastically. My favorite moment camera wise is a shot where Hepburn is upset that the crooks cut her phone line, and the shot featuring stair railings makes her look like she's locked up in some prison cell somewhere. But nothing can be more suspenseful than the 20-minute finale in the dark. I was told that the ending was one of the most frightening, psychologically insane sequences ever, and guess what? I was told well. 

Also making the film work well are its acting performances. I was skeptical of Alan Arkin playing a sadistic crook, as I'm used to seeing him in goofy, comedic roles, but Arkin surprisingly nails his character. It's probably the best you'll ever see of Arkin, as this is likely the only time he played a role this complex. Another surprising performance is Julie Herrod as the girl Gloria. I thought she would be this obnoxious brat (as her opening scene would suggest), but I applaud the filmmakers for making the character feel more natural in what a child would do in tense situations. But it's Audrey Hepburn who gives the best performance as Susy the blind housewife. In something that was groundbreaking for 1967, we are treated to one, self reliant, independent, and resourceful woman. And Hepburn plays a role unlike any other character she's played, and was deserving of her Best Actress nom.

If Henry Mancini did not score Wait Until Dark, I'm not sure if the film would work in the suspense department. It's chilling, it's eerie, and the odd-sounding chords are just downright creepy! It's safe to say that this is one of Mancini's best scores, along with The Pink Panther, The Great Race, and Charade. 

Wait Until Dark does what a great suspense thriller should do. It's highly entertaining, the performances are outstanding, the score is chilling, and the filming techniques are the most innovative I've seen in the world of suspense thrillers, creating the psychological, claustrophobic look that sums up the greatness of the film as a whole. If Charade is considered the greatest Hitchcock film that Hitchcock never made, then this would be the second best!
